[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: OK, item 12, negotiations and legal matters.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A motion to go into executive session.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So moved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So moved by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot, seconded by Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Van der Kloot?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We will now enter executive session.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good evening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My name is Stephanie Muccini-Burke and I'm running for re-election to be your mayor, the chief executive officer of the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you for being here tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Like you, I chose to reside and raise my family here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Having graduated from Medford High, I earned a bachelor's degree in business from Suffolk University and a master's in taxation from Bentley University.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My husband Brian and I have three beautiful children who have all attended public schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am and always have been invested in this community and will continue to be its champion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I believe that 15 years as your city councilor, five years as the city's director of budget and personnel, 25 years as a licensed certified public accountant opening my own small business here in Medford, and just under two years as your mayor makes me the most qualified person to be the chief executive officer of the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My administration has and will continue to be a responsible steward of all taxpayers' hard-earned dollars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We will continue to aggressively pursue grant funding to leverage our dollars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford's high quality bond rating is no accident.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is the result of careful planning and the prudent expenditure of municipal funds for projects that better our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In under two years, we've accomplished much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've contracted for professional management of the Chevalier Theater to Bill Blumenreich Presents of the Wilbur.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This will be a catalyst in the Medford Square Master Plan that we worked on collaboratively with residents and business owners, many of you here tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have implemented the complete streets methodology with projects being done in every section of the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am very proud of tackling the issue of the need for a new police station head on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our fine law enforcement personnel deserve nothing less as they go about serving the safety needs of our residents every hour of every day of every night.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In the world in which we live, safety can never be taken for granted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The needs of our public safety employees are many, and they must continually be addressed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have done just that in year one alone of the five-year capital plan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The city has purchased 12 new cruisers, breathing apparatus and turnout gear for our firefighters, new trucks and equipment for our DPW.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I want to continue to move Medford into a brighter future.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To do it, one will need to be inclusive, respectful, and equipped to do the job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One must listen, be organized, and ready to lead.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am that candidate that has the critical attributes necessary to move all of Medford forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You deserve a mayor that can effectuate change.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I believe that my experience, leadership, style, and ability to collaborate will help deliver on core local services and help ensure economic opportunity for everyone in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I ask you, do you want to continue to bring meaningful change to the city, our city with a person that has a proven track record of accomplishment?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I hope so.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think it's our infrastructure that is probably the most demanding and complex thing that we have for the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have aging infrastructure for our water and sewer pipes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have streets that we're working on that are in pretty poor shape and we need to address those.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Systematically, so we've been spending a lot of time over the course of the last two years looking at the Complete Streets Program so that we can address our main drags and get them up to tip-top shape and also make them safe in the way that we do it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's a whole new approach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We feel strongly that you need to look at our streets not only for cars but for people and pedestrians and for people on bicycles and wheelchairs and handicapped accessibility issues.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think that that is the most important issue that we need to face right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And definitely we are on our way to doing that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With miles of roadway in the city of Medford, we are attacking streets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're making it a priority, and we're looking at it from the ground up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have put funding in place.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: From the state, we were able to get a $400,000 grant after signing the community compact with the lieutenant governor just two months in my first term.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That enabled us to put together a complete streets policy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And from there, we now are out in the roads.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are doing the work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I hope that you'll spend some time, look at High Street, because that's where we're taking it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that will be going all over the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have the Haines Square project.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everyone knows Spring Street and Salem Street and how that intersection is tremendously difficult to navigate, not only for people, but for vehicles.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that is being worked on right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we think that that will be a fine addition to the Salem Street area as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But it's happening all throughout the community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I definitely support charter review.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I actually offered a home rule petition to the city council in order to get it through the state legislature so the people that have been trying to get signatures for I think three years now, some of them are in this room, we could cut out that process so we could go right to the ballot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Unfortunately, with a four to three city council vote, the state legislature doesn't give much merit to a home rule for that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They really like to see community support in order to move a home rule through.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So unfortunately, that did not pass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I do believe in charter review.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I personally like WAD representation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know some people don't.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I tend to like WAD representation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think it would make sense.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ideally, I wouldn't like to see a huge council.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I wouldn't like to see it greater than seven.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if we could maybe look at two wards at a time, so we'd have four at large and three ward representatives, I'm sorry, four ward representatives and three at large.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think that would be a fabulous mix.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think we would get a lot of business done in the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that is one of the critical things.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And what I hear on the streets, and I'm sure David hears it too, is four-year mirror, because you're in such a short period of time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and now you're spending time in an election and that goes for the city council as well, a new city councilor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that that's something that should be looked at as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Certainly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've offered many home rule petitions in the city of Medford, and most of them are, you know, six to one votes, seven unanimous.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The legislature does not look at four to three while it is a simple majority.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They do not put weight in that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They do not think that you're really crying out for change.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that's what happens up at the state legislature, and we did fight, we did try to get it passed, more so for the people that are collecting the signatures, because they deserve to have that ballot question put on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that is a very important thing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think everything should be reviewed when you review a ballot on the charter.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You should look at all facets of it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And certainly, I support that wholeheartedly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Mr. Kennedy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The parking program, while not perfect, and I'll agree, it's not perfect, we have tweaked it tremendously in probably the first six months when I took office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is an app on your phone that you can pay for your parking.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've dropped the app fee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was 35 cents when we entered the contract.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have it down to a nickel for Medford residents in order to use the app fee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We did a business add-on program so that if you were at the doctor's office or you were getting your hair done or anything, any service you were having done in the squares, the business owner can add time to your vehicle so that you don't have to go out because it was a bone of contention at the beginning that some things take more than two hours and if you parked on the street, that's the limit.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we made that change as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We made the lots, turned them into three-hour lots.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We did a senior sticker for $25 per year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A senior not only gets the sticker and doesn't have to visit a kiosk or a meter anywhere in the city, but they also have an extra hour on street that they're able to park, a great benefit to our senior citizens as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are waiting right now for the Charlie car.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's the piece that I've been pushing for and it comes from the actually developer of the parking kiosk itself, not the, not Republic Parking.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we are waiting on a trolley car that would work similar to your T-pass and just stick it in and it just has your plate on it so you don't have to do anything else.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I do want to mention that there's an amortization schedule that's attached to the contract.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if you were to try to buy out of that contract right now today, it would be $522,000 that the city would have to pay to buy out of the contract.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Plus we lose about a little under $500,000 in miscellaneous receipts that we're receiving right now from our parking program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So those two things would go away, then we'd have to buy all new equipment in order to get a program back up in the street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I've talked to a lot of business owners, and they know that now there is turnover on the street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Prior cars were parking there and taking the bus into town.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now there's turnover.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Your customers have a place to park now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that is a very positive thing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I also just wanted to throw out there that we put forth a package to the council for $250,000 to be spent in the various business districts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that money, $50,000 per district, certainly could purchase single head meters if that was what the calling was for, or it could be used for beautification.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're working with the chamber.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They put together a committee so that we can work on this directly and come up with a plan for that $250,000, which is what the council wants to see.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They want to see details of how it will be spent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that's one thing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You know, this parking program kind of noosed me two years ago, and I know that it's an issue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we've tried so hard to make changes that make sense and that make it easier.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I really urge people, when you go to Somerville and you go to Boston and you're using your phone to pay for your parking, you can do that in Medford too.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we've gotten the word out there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So just use your phone.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's so easy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's how I travel.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's what I do when I stop during the day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So make sure that you load up that app and you use it, because it is a huge benefit.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think it's really important as part of our Medford Square master plan that we've just finished the work on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The report is online at the City of Medford website.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's mixed use.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mixed use is what we have in Station Landing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It works in other communities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We really need to build up the mixed use features in Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You do see it to a small degree, but it's not very dense when you look at two stories maybe above the storefronts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think it's really important that we add that element to Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a zoning amendment that is going to be offered to the city council very shortly so that we can work collaboratively with them as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Secondly, on Mystic Avenue, we just received another grant in order to look at the Mystic Avenue corridor for zoning, specifically for zoning purpose.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we want to walk away at the end of this process with an actual amendment that can then go to the city council and they know that everyone has worked on this process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So those are two key elements that I think will add businesses to the square and also the mixed use so you bring people that will now go into the businesses.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But it's really important, I think, for us to be recruiting businesses, a diversified business base.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that's where the city and the chamber work together in order to look at businesses that we think are lacking in the square and try to reach out and recruit them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've tried that in a couple of occasions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I have a business liaison in my office

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have attempted to reach out and try to get certain types of business into the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that you were saying all these grand openings that we're having, there's a lot going on in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think if you look at the types of restaurants in Medford Square in particular, you can eat pretty much anything from any country and we have it there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there is a great diversity of restaurants right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I differ from his opinion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think the master plan has been a very concerted effort on the part of businesses, residents who came out to all the meetings in order to get it to be what we want it to be.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That plan will use shared parking.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's not going to create more parking.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's going to use shared parking.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the people that live in the units during the day and go to work,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Their spaces will open up and the businesses will use them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that's how we're going to network the parking issue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that's really an important element as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're not going to lose 40% of the parking spaces in Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I guarantee you that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That will not happen.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The other thing about the master plan is to bring businesses and mixed use to the river.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Right now we're not embracing the river.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a huge asset for us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we need to do better work at that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that's what this master plan is leading us to.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The development.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: closer to the river along the City Hall line where there's so much open space there that we can really capitalize on to create this mixed-use vibrant downtown so people can enjoy the multitude of restaurants that are already there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I just shut off.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, first off, I think in part of all of the development that we're going to see, which Medford is a very popular place to be, and if we do some of these mixed-use projects, we will have additional housing opportunities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the key to that is including the affordability component into every new building that goes on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Currently, we're acquiring 10%.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That number will probably be increased in the very near future.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The other thing is an inclusionary zoning ordinance that will up that percentage.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And what it does is it gives developers an opportunity that if you do more affordable housing, we'll let you maybe get away with a few less parking spaces.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So you're actually working with developers so that you get a mix that works for the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think inclusionary zoning is, it can be a voluntary basis where if they do more, they may not have to reach some of the setbacks and things of that nature that go along with zoning.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As many people know, we did a mixed-use zone down in Station Landing, and I think that that is really, it was one of the first mixed-use, first transit-oriented development zoning opportunities that we had.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we see how it has worked and how it has benefited the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we need some of that, and we need some more commercial entities so that we can continue to spread the tax burden across all the different elements.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that those two things combined will be very productive for the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I don't know if many of you in the audience know, but pretty much every year, certainly in the last 25, the tax burden has been shifted to the greatest degree to commercial entities as opposed to the residential.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have done that over and over again.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: City Council has voted for that tax relief for the residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know it's still hard on the pocket, but with rising costs,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Things don't stay stable.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's rising costs out there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's salaries that are increasing, and there's infrastructure needs that we need to pay for.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we need to do what's within prop two and a half, which is we have totally complied with, and we need to figure out how to best spend that money.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that's, those are some things that we have to do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But getting back to the river, that's the point.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That was the point I was making is we need to move everything to the river, but we need to have the footpaths that go in front of the houses so that we continue on

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: with all the connectivity that we're doing right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I also want to see housing and mixed use closer to the river so that we can benefit from it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a huge asset.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It has been ignored for too long.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it is a priority.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that is part of the master plan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, we put together, with the great help of our council president,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: in seven months a grant application that normally takes communities two to three years to do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Of course, when we put in that application, we thought that we would be maybe in phase two of the allotment of the grant if we were even successful.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When we got the word that we were in the first round, which is this year, we all kind of went into a little bit of a panic because we wanted to put a foundation in place a year and a half prior to being able to utilize the grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With that being said, we have put together a form to foundation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They will be seeking out contributions in order to hopefully match what the state has put up, which is about $12.6 million.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a huge grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very optimistic from those that have already been interviewed and people that we have reached out to that we will be able to parlay the state grant, double it with the foundation money, and then be left for the city to put up a piece, which is about $5 million, which is the goal.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very optimistic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are embracing the new library.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I wholeheartedly support it, or I would not have asked for the committee to be put together to get the grant even off the ground.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think everybody knows, and I've said it at every meeting, every public meeting that I've been at, if I ask someone to do something, it's not just to put it on the shelf.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's really to enact it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you for all the hard work, the people that worked on that building committee, Mr. Caraviello.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As everyone knows, we have appropriated $2 million for new police headquarters.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This talk about it not happening or that it's fictitious is so inaccurate.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've put the money up, $2 million.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The architect meets every single week.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have an onus project manager, an OPM on board that meets with us as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and the engineer from the city hall and we also have the chief who's put together a team of police officers of all ranks and all sexes to go around and visit various police stations around us so that we can get the best with our plan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So to say that the police department is not a priority of mine is very disingenuous because that was the priority and that is why we're working so hard to get it done.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, yes, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I've talked to Congresswoman Clark, all of our US senators.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is no grant money for police stations for infrastructure.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're not there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We had the director of public safety for the state of Massachusetts walk through our police station, agree with us that it is in deplorable condition, and then said, walk up to Lawrence and go look at theirs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then you're going to say Medford is not as bad as Lawrence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's what they told us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is no funding, unlike the schools, that you can go to the MSBA and get 54, 55 percent match.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's no funding out there for public safety.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I've raised that with our state delegation as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I've raised it with the governor and the lieutenant governor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everyone's saying it's a great idea, but they need to figure out how they can get the money in order to match the city of Medford and all these other communities that are dealing with crumbling stations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a priority.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A little bit more.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You people want to see this?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: For those of you that understand,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: government and how it works.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's not fast.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Procurement takes time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We had to go out and procure for the architect.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We had to go out and procure for the owner's project manager.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You have to follow all these steps in government in order to get things done.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We had to know how big we were building the station and we had to find a location for it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We talked to every owner of property in the city of Medford, from up in the hillside area to Wellington to the courthouse, the Cambridge courthouse that sits in the city of Medford and doesn't service us as a district court.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've talked to every person to see if there was a place that we could get into

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: little quicker.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When all was said and done, a lot of the officers that I spoke to said, we like being right here in the heart of Medford that we can get to any location in minutes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We like this location.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that's what drove us back to the training facility, which is where we're building it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So in the next probably six months, you're going to see that building come down, and then you're going to see a new structure go up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I know many of the offices in this room tonight have been part of this process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They've looked at the plans.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They've chosen an option because there were two that were just delivered to them in the last two weeks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They've selected the option that they like best, and that's where we're going with this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a crisis and we need to just face the fact it is a crisis and it is a priority for cities, towns, states across this country and we have been

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: fortunate in obtaining grant money so that we can attempt to fight this horrible disease that it has turned into.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have received grants for the school department so that they're doing educational programs, because it all starts with education.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: At the end of the day, that's where it all starts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You need to teach the kids to stay on the track.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we've also expanded that in the city of Medford with our opioid team, our team Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: that meets with not only people suffering from opioid addiction in the schools and in the city, but the trades.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is so commonplace in the trades.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When we've done our analyses, they've shown 40% of all the opioid issues that come through the public safety arena

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: are people from the trades because of the hard work that they do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Because when they get injured, they have to get some medicine to get through the day because they need to put food on the table for their family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have found that there is a huge issue there as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we've been devoting a lot of time and energy to meeting with the unions and the tradesmen as a whole.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: so that we can get to them and try to provide them help.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, for the first time, we've offered a budget item that started July 1st for a full-time recovery coach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This young man is out in the neighborhoods.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's talking to people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's educating people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And he's working hand-in-hand with the school nurses, the teachers, all the extracurricular programs that are there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: to work with them, the coaches, who sometimes may be the first line of defense to see things that are going on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if they know what to look for, they can catch things earlier.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have been doing that in a concerted effort, and we're meeting with the district attorney, Ryan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She holds monthly meetings at Lawrence Memorial Hospital.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a team of police chiefs and doctors and nurses from all across the region that touch Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We meet there monthly in order to do best practices so that we can figure out how can we move forward to curb this epidemic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We meet regularly in the city of Medford on this topic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have plans.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've had in plain sight exposs in City Hall.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've set up a room so the parents know what to look for.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You would be amazed at things that are right in front of your face.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: that have bottoms that pop out of them, and things are in them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we did in plain sight, and I don't think I saw anyone here at that event, but there were a lot of people from the general public that came out to it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you for coming.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was an informative night.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We hold these all the time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's so much going on in the city because we want to get to the parents so that they can see what's transpiring, so they can

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: see that little, that something about their child, something has gone wrong that they can correct and catch it early.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're doing that through education in our school system and the city of Medford playing a very active role in outreach as well as providing an educational support system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And believe me, that office has a little army.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's about seven people in that office and we meet regularly on it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, we are actually in the process of expanding.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you looked at this year's budget, we put in monies for January to start a civilian staffing of our 9-1-1 program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So what that will do is the money that will be spent on the civilian staffing will free up officers that are in there now, generally three at the time, will be back in force.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that's three on a given shift.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we will have about seven extra offices that are basically being added to patrol and or

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: traffic, whatever the case may be.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So what we did with this year's budget was a reallocation by putting in the civilian.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're able to garner additional people that can be out in the streets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that's very important.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, I think if you look at the budget, you have a limited amount of money that you can spend.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so we have to allocate that source of funding across all different spectrums.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And there's a lot of important things going on in the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So from that regard, we did increase the police budget, which I thought was warranted, and we will be seeing increases probably going forward as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I did want to just add one thing on foot patrols.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We did implement a change in the way that our sector cars are dispersed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So right now, they're regularly out of the vehicles, walking the squares, meeting the business owners and the constituents that are there every single day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we did put that in place, and Chief Sacco has been very on top of making sure that that happens.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So a lot of the calls in when we've discovered people that were living under our footbridge in Medford Square that no one knew was living there because of the foot patrol.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they were able to discover a lot of those types of things.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They've also been able to move people along if they're loitering.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they've also just gotten to know people a little bit better.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're big supporters of that, obviously.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Likewise, I'm a huge advocate for that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think arts and culture really are an economic catalyst for downtowns.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We see that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's why we've spent so much time on the Chevalier Theatre.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think that that is an immense opportunity to bring thousands of people, the theatre holds 2,000 people, to shows on an ongoing basis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Once that is up and running and we have people in there, it's

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: New Year's Eve, his first act.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then we have some other things coming up there too.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Frankie Valli showing up in April.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So once they're in there and having their shows regularly, it is a catalyst for economic growth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But to talk to arts and culture, when I talk to people, they talk about the single artist.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They want to expose their work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They want to show their work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We created a forum in City Hall where every month we're flipping out different artists and their work so that it's on display.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you come up, come up our two hallways and you can see all the beautiful artwork that citizens are producing on a regular basis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've paid attention to that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Part of the Riverside Plaza project that we're putting up will have another location to be the mecca for all opportunities for the city to invest in events.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have some of the great people here this evening that put them on, and they put them on in a parking lot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They just want to put them on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're that eager.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we look forward to working with you for a beautiful space, City Hall now being one of the key locations that will be able to house a lot of different events going on in the city in a very safe environment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But, you know, Bill Blumenrecht, I can't say enough about him, what he has done with the Wilbur.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And he has already gotten into the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's meeting with the chamber in another month, but he's met with the friends of the Chevalier in order to really figure out what are they all about and how can we best use that asset in order to move the city forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really proud of that, and we think that art belongs in every neighborhood.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're also working on some sides of buildings and we're trying to get some of the landlords to approve that we can do murals on the sides of buildings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're in it in a host of ways and I have a cultural liaison that deals with this stuff every single day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That should be an issue for most of us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But one of the things that will happen, the Board of Health plays an active role in giving out the victualist license.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It actually, through a home rule petition, it's actually the licensing commission of the city of Medford that will be handling both the liquor license as well as the common victualist.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But of course, the Board of Health plays a major role in supporting that effort.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you can't open up until you've qualified through all the different serve safes and all those other programs that are mandated by the state to do business.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we will obviously be complying with that facet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I also just wanted to add one thing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When I was a Councilor, I made a promise to the art community that when we get Medford Square off the ground, there would be a space for them to have their home.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Because as we all know, they had a little spot in the mall

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: for a while that really worked out well, but they lost that when the mall turned into the plaza, the Wegmans that it will be on Sunday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I promised them that when I was a Councilor, and I hold my promises seriously, and that will be taking place when we do the revitalization and we do the mixed use in Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They will have a home, and I guarantee them today on this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, I just wanted to add a little bit about the economic engine.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We were just listed as one of the top 10 cities in the country.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that wasn't by accident.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They actually wrote up the Mystic River Celebration, which Cachet is responsible for.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That played a huge role in us getting that ranking because we have so many great events that are going on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know if you visited the farmer's market over the summer, you got to see some of those events with musicians playing, artwork displaying.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our restaurants partner with the artists.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They display artwork as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a very rich community here, and I don't want anyone to walk out of here tonight and think that we don't, because it is a great community, we have fabulous businesses, they embrace the artists and we're collaboratively with them, so I just want everyone to realize that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We put forth a resolution that the city council signed on to, the school committee signed on to, and our human rights commission signed on to, making us a welcoming city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're very proud of that moment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It also goes into the discussions that are being held throughout the community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the second piece of that was the Safe Community Act, which is a state

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: the state legislature, I think over 50 state legislatures, Senate and House, have signed on to the Safe Communities Act that they're trying to push for the state.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Because it's important for it to be an umbrella.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: People can't go from one community where they're safe to another community where they're in harm's way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that that's a really important act and that's what would end up making sense.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But if you read it,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Sanctuary City really isn't defined anywhere.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a philosophy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's how you treat people that you come across.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So when we've had issues, I met with the chief and his echelon of officers to speak to him about what happens now so that we could understand.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you pull someone over, what happens?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you arrest someone for shoplifting, what happens?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So basically, if someone is arrested and brought to the station, they're fingerprinted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And when a fingerprint happens, it's sent up to the federal government.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if it's someone that has a warrant, is known, something comes back and they ask the city to either hold the person or then they would go to the courts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Because generally, a bill has already happened and these people have already moved through our system by the time the federal government gets back to you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So what I wanted to make sure with the chief was that if someone is volunteering information about a crime, then we're not asking them, are you a U.S.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: citizen?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It really doesn't matter.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We want them to be volunteering information to us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We can't put up that wall where suddenly they feel like they're going to be scooted away, an ice truck and a black limo is going to come and take them away.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: but that they're safe enough to report crimes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And to me, that's the balance is having safety of individuals and also information coming forward so that we can solve crimes and know when something's happening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's a tough issue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know there's a lot of emotion surrounding it, but we need to understand how the city operates now in order to know that we're doing what we care to do and what's important to do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm fine, thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: First off, I think I might have mentioned a little earlier, it was one of the first initiatives that we signed on to as a city was the community compact for complete streets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think it's a best practice.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Some communities had already started doing it, and we thought it was important for us to embrace this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When you hear people talk about complete streets, it has to be part of your DNA.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It has to be how you live and breathe, creating your road structures.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think it's really important.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The question, piece of the question was how far along are we?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We finished, Boston Ave has a complete bike lane.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So hopefully, I've heard great things from the people that reside in this neighborhood at some of the improvements that we've done in the Hillside neighborhood.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So from Boston Ave, from High Street all the way to the Somerville line, you either have a bike route dedicated to you or sharrows where it becomes too narrow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I agree, when it becomes too narrow, it's a,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a state level issue, bikes and cars sharing roads, but it's at the state level.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're doing the sharrows there, so at least there is an eye alert that bikes have as much privilege to the roads as cars do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've also are looking at Winthrop Circle.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're doing extensions of the curbing at Winthrop Circle so that we can make that crosswalk much safer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: High Street in front of the Brooks School, we had a couple of incidents there, so we are implementing best practices there as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think if anyone drives there right now, you'll see the work that's being, is underway as we speak.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And following up, once that work is done, that whole road will be repaved because we held off on the paving contract, obviously, so that we could finish the complete streets first.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But to me, one of the most vital areas is the Haines Square area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The Spring Street to Salem is just very dangerous.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have pictures at some of our presentations of people with their carriages trying to get to the plaza there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they're basically walking through parking lots that cars are going back and forth in.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we think that's a critical piece and we're going to be using Chapter 90 funds in order to pay for that because it is that important.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So just to capture some of it, we have Chapter 90 from the state.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They give us a bucket of money, about a little under a million dollars each year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It comes out in April.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: From that, we determine the road projects that we're going to do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I've been on, I'm on record as saying we're addressing the main thoroughfares in the community before we spend that money on side streets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think it's really important to get our main roads up to snuff.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They've been let go too long.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we are focusing our attention on the main roads, and then we will trickle into the neighborhoods.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When water and sewer projects are happening, roads will be fixed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But roads will be fixed with a complete street perspective, which is very important.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you for giving me a little extra time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When you can have a bike path off the roads, that's the best thing you can do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that's the clipper ship connector that we've been working on so that bikes don't have to travel along with cars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We obviously all agree, I think everyone agrees, that that's the best thing you can do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But of course, you can't do that everywhere.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So when you do share a road, you share the road.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the bikes have as much privilege to the road as the car does.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we think it's very important that if they're going to be sharing, that we try to make it as safe as possible for them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All of the roads, like Boston Ave, for example, all meet federal guidelines for transportation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We don't just willy-nilly go out there and say, we're going to make this lane 10 feet and that lane 11.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's all structured by what the minimum lane width is by federal standards.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we meet them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Second, I just wanted to mention in regards to the high street area for the Brooks School, they started a walk to school program several years ago and they were parents mainly started this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they were lucky enough, we have secured a million dollar grant from the State Department of Transportation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And what it's going to do, it's going to take you from Alston Street down to Woburn Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So now, we're going to have complete streets from all the way from Woburn to the train tracks in West Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And what that did, now that has prompted all of our other elementary schools to get on board with this Safe Routes to School Program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So now the Roberts, they have Walking Wednesdays.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they're trying to build up their inventory of events that they do so then we can apply for the grants and we can do that for the Roberts School and continue it along to the Columbus.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that's what our goal is.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'm just really proud to announce that it was really parent-driven, this million-dollar grant that we've received.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the Department of Transportation is leading it up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, I think if anyone even watches this campaign cycle, we haven't, we've been above board the entire way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everyone that has worked on this campaign has acted that way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm really proud that we're both here today and that we have run a really clean,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: respectful campaign, so thank you for that, and thank you to everyone who has participated thus far, because that's really important.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I hear all too often people that are so frustrated with the federal level, so frustrated with what's going on, but they know at home we can make change.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We can participate.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We can come to you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Do you know how many community events we have and people just show up because they want to feel part of something positive?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really, really thrilled with all of the outreach that we've done and the people that have committed to assisting us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've had so many committees and so many efforts because people know that we're listening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And again, the vow is if you participate,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm not dictating.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: At the end of it all, we will implement what you are suggesting, and we saw that clearly with the Medford Square program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think from a civility standpoint, people need to know that your elected officials here at home respect you, and hopefully you will respect us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everyone knows there's the midnight warriors that are behind keyboards.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They say nasty, nasty things, not only about candidates, but about their families.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's disgusting, and it's vile.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I hope that people out there, when they go home tonight, that they're respectful behind their computer and just know that we're respectful back to you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think that's really, really important.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if I could drill that in, I would say that every single day to people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Just think before you type because it's there, it's there forever, and you can't take it back.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it just really brings down democracy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Again, we have so many fabulous people in the city of Medford that stand tall,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: at a phone call, we need your help to get this off the ground or to get that off the ground or to come down to the happy birthday party and cut how many slices of cake.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We need people that are always, that step up and we are so very blessed to have those people in the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I go to work every single day and I love my job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: because it's really not a job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I get to meet fabulous people every single day that give their hearts and souls to make this city great.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I respect you all so very much, and I appreciate the hard work that you do, oftentimes without a pat on the back, except, you know, hopefully I'm saying thank you, because I tend to.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But a lot of people just do it to do it, because they want to feel involved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They want to feel connected.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we are very, very blessed to have those people in our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm proud to be a lifelong Medford resident.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm proud that I opened my business up in Medford Square when I had my CPA firm for 10 years in Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm proud of choosing to stay in Medford like you may have chosen to reside in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am very proud of that, and I love this city dearly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And there's not a thing that I could do that would ever put harm to this community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I so love it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it's part of us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's part of me.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's part of my family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we do everything for this city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I just wanted to commend the members of the CPA, CPC, Community Preservation Committee, for all of their hard work and outreach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's a perfect example of how you do it right.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They've had so many public forums, they've had so many public meetings, and they really are inclusive of everyone from sending information, not just, normally we use the database of property owners.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Clearly, we don't want just property owners being at the table.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we actually reached out to get tenants so that we could figure out a way to have their voices heard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: From an inclusion perspective, I think my office and City Hall in particular, we have made such advancement in including people and also in diversity.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really proud of the positions we've taken and the appointments that we've made.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: to really look outside of traditional and try to do things in the best interest of this community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you to the Chamber of Commerce and Tufts University for hosting this evening and all those in attendance or watching from home.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is certainly an exciting time in our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: From the positive write-ups in Boston.com to number four zip code in the U.S., Medford is a great place to live.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The level of civic engagement is amazing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I thank each and every one of you that has volunteered on committees, attended the hundreds of public forums we have held, come to Council on Aging for our monthly updates,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I hope that the parents in the audience have heard of the many visits I have made to the classroom and events in our public schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I have met so many residents who have shared their life stories with me, from the Vietnamese man who was so proud to provide a safe life for his family and to be a U.S.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: citizen, to the Haitian mom who came here for a better life.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Simply astounding individuals, and I am humbled that you trust your stories to me, and I appreciate your support.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You will elect a CEO who will lead the city forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To do so, we need to continue to focus on being a welcoming community for all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: affecting revitalization of our squares, implementing the five-year capital plan, continue the complete streets program, review zoning ordinance throughout our city, including Mystic Avenue, invest in our public schools, and get the positive word out that we are a great place to live, work, and play in.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These will continue to be at the forefront of my administration.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our next mayor has the opportunity to lead Medford into a brighter future, not only for us, but for our children and grandchildren.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To do it, one will need to be inclusive, respectful, and equipped for the job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One must listen, be organized, and ready to lead.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am the candidate that has the attributes to move all of Medford forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I have and will hit the ground running.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you want someone who provides solutions and builds Medford up, you have a clear choice.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you want an honest CEO who is champion for this city, you have a clear choice.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you want someone that has the experience necessary to run a city, you have a clear choice.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Together, we will write another chapter.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: make change happen, and be partners in progress.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I ask you, are you ready to continue to bring about change to our city?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With a person that has a proven track record, I am prepared, I am ready, and I ask you for one of your votes on Tuesday, November 7th.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Please reelect myself, Stephanie Mugini-Burke, for mayor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you and God bless.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This really is an honor for me to be here today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know that Mr. Camargo and Mr. Orlando have been working diligently for years to try to get a plaque to memorialize the Citizens of the Year of the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've had some amazing people that have come from our city and they've done so many things on behalf of our citizens.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So really today is a day to honor their service, their commitment to our community, and also just so that when people pass through this beautiful building, they can come up, take a look, and they can see some of the spectacular names.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I know that you're going to recognize many of them, and you'll remember the story of what they did when they did travel through these halls and through the City of Bedford Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So everybody, at this point, I want to introduce Mr. Fred Dello Russo.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He is one of our city councilors, and he would like to, this plaque has a special place in his heart that he'd like to express to you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Dello Russo.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you can see, this wall is a living wall.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we look forward in the future to add new names to it each and every year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the list that Dawn just read off, some amazing, amazing people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're just really privileged to have known as many of them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I know some of you have traveled so far.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: From Maine, the Zamperales are down from Maine.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and New Hampshire.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: People are here from all the greater New England states, and I believe one from maybe Florida, too.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you all for making this trip up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're really celebrating life here today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This building, we restored it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Between myself and the city council, we put a little over $2 million into restoration for this lovely building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think when you walk through it, you're probably not going to notice any changes because we're really trying to stay true to its integrity.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But this foyer really is a welcoming point for our city government.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I hope that people will come in and spend some time here and really look at these names and think of some of the stories.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're talking about in the future maybe having an electronic storytelling machine in here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So you could actually look at a name and then listen about what your family says about them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we plan on doing that in the very near future.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think if you turn around and you look directly across from me, we have Mayor Irwin.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have his portrait as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mayor Irwin was instrumental in obtaining the funding for this building and seeing the construction start.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And his granddaughter, Anne Marie, actually is our treasurer today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So talk about life is a big circle, and it's just really a privilege and honor to be able to recognize Mayor Irwin as well for his deeds in building this gorgeous building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Happy 80th birthday, Medford City Hall!

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hi, everybody.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thanks again for walking out here so that we can pay tribute to more home and veteran citizens that gave so much to this community and made it the great community that it is today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: First, I would like to recognize some of our elected officials that are in the audience.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: From the City Council, we have President Rick Caraviello.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Michael Marks, George Scarpelli, Adam Knight, John Falco, and Fred Dello Russo.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And bring them on over here, everyone.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: From our school committee, we have Kathy Kreatz, Amory Cuno, Aaron DiBenedetto, and Bob Skerry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Welcome.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have our representative, Paul Donato, here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have former Mayor Michael J. McGlynn is present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There are some people that touch your lives and they really have an impact, an impact on you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you know that everything they did was for the betterment of others.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Steve Honeycutt was that man.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He never put himself first.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He always wanted to be there to speak for those that couldn't.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And he led this city so strongly in the Human Rights Commission and the Persons with Disability Commission to make sure that all those had a voice.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're very blessed today to have many members of his family here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if I could just acknowledge the Honeycutt family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have Steve's wife Diane, his daughters Stacey and Perry Royce, granddaughter Erin,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: His mom, Elaine Honeycutt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Brother, Billy Honeycutt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Sister, Barbara Sherratt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nephew, Matthew Sherratt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: His nephew, David Honeycutt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And his sister-in-law, Heath Honeycutt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hopefully, I recognize the Honeycutt family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so, I'm sorry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: very important to us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have someone with us, our former diversity director, Diane McLeod, who had the honor and privilege of working with Stephen on so many causes over the course of her tenure with the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled that Diane came back today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You know, we're trying to get her back a little bit more, but we're happy to have her back today because she would not miss this for the world, and she wants to pay her tribute to Stephen.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Diane.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This time we'd like to invite members of the family to unveil.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Stephen C. Honeycutt, Chairperson, Medford Commission for Persons with Disabilities, appointed 1993 to 2015.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He lit the way for disability issues for an entire community and stood for those individuals facing challenges, dedicated this day, October 19, 2017, by myself.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a little darker by now, and we have this great plan to light up City Hall on the roof.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And unfortunately we moved along a little too quick, but hopefully you'll come back because part of this, he did look like the way for Medford and for people, and he always taught me to have a strong voice.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so come back, please look at it, and then see the lights that are around because they reflect him.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you all very, very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Happy 80th birthday, Medford City Hall.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much for being here this evening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This really is an honor for me to be able to spend some time with the Lee family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I mean, I got to know Richard a little differently than most of you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I see all of his girls that he has in the office, and it's appropriate to say so, and his family members.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I got to know Richard Lee through baseball.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our two old boys play ball together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I quickly learned that he had a dry sense of humor and a really clever wit.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you never quite knew if he was kidding or not.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it was always a fun day when we went to the park.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So much so that, like I said, my older boy played with his son Andrew, my son Ryan and Andrew.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I had a middle guy named Connor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And for some reason, Richard decided to rename him Harry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Why?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I have no idea, but it stuck.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Harry, when he walked in the park and he saw Richard, eyes lit up and he just was like a magnet going over to him.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I was really blessed to have Richard in my life before I took public service on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then of course, being a Councilor and being a CPA at budget time, Richard and I returned into

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We butted our heads together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it was always professional.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We always walked away at the end of budget hearings and could have a laugh together, could shake hands.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that's the way it's supposed to be.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You're supposed to be able to leave everything in the room and then go out and be cordial, be friends.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that's one thing that Richard always taught me is that life is bigger than the job and make sure you always do your best.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: work hard, and you know at the end of the day that you did something good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm really blessed to be here, and I'm with his wife.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: His wife Cheryl is here in attendance as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Sherry, we all call her.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: His lovely daughter Megan is here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: His eldest son Andrew.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Mikey would love to be here, but unfortunately he couldn't attend today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But it's just a beautiful family, caring people, and they always gave back to their community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So to me, when I walk down this hall, I think it's just the right place for Richard to be.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we get to share with him every day and I can feel his eyes on me right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think Harry's at the back of the room and he's feeling his eyes on him right now too.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But without further ado, I would like to introduce one of his best friends, Mark Brumley, who got to work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He got to play, he got to go to proms, he got to work with Richard, and I know that every day Mark misses Richard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So Mark, please step forward and speak about your friend.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Harry is unique.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So at this time, the Lee family would like to officially take the chair.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Here you go.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Let's see that beautiful name.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a modern hug.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much for being a part of this beautiful celebration of life tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you all have heard, possibly during the course of the evening, this lovely building turned 80 years old under temporal weather.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So, of course, we had the work underway.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You notice that we did the beautiful plaster job and restored all of the woodwork that had been damaged through leaking and ruining.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we did a new roof on the top and a new dome.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the front, of course, fully handicapped accessible.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really proud of the building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: New doors are coming.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're just waiting a couple of weeks for them to be installed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There will be new front doors that will open automatically and whatnot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So fully accessible, which is our goal in Bedford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you all for being here tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I want to thank the alumni again for participating.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're going to be doing a happy birthday tomorrow in a few minutes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we also have students from Bedford High School that were up in the lobby that have been playing all evening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So make sure you talk to them about thank you and what a nice job they do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're really blessed in Bedford to have a rich music program and we're thankful that the kids are always willing to step up and participate and come out and add colors to our band.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you alumni, thank you Bedford High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you know that every year they hold an event right here in the communal chamber where they auction off trees and all sorts of different things.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And most of the money goes towards the community family for our hearts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we want to thank the Jingle Bell ladies for helping us all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Oh, yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yeah, sure.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be my guest.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion for suspension of the rules.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Stone would like to discuss something.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Great.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yep.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have one item.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nelson would like to explain something about our upcoming Committee of the Whole meeting regarding the new MCAS.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Are there any questions?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to receive this paper and place it on file.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You have a request?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a follow-up?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One more.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion on the floor to accept this report and place it on file by Mr. Skerry, seconded by Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Aye.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I just want to make a general announcement.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: At 5 o'clock on Thursday, we're having a birthday party for this building, as well as dedicating
