[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So come on down should be a fun night birthday cake and Food so come on down and there's a motion to adjourn this meeting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Oh, no.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: No, we're going into executive session Motion to go into executive session seconded by mr. Benedetto roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Scurry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, I

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, six in the affirmative, none in the negative, one absent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We'll now enter executive session.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much for participating tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hello and welcome to our beautiful, state-of-the-art Community Media Center located within the Medford Vocational Technical High School campus.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This studio encompasses all areas of access television, while incorporating courses for students in the new media technology program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're thrilled to make this an inspiring, inclusive space for all to learn and have their voices heard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To see this project come to fruition is a remarkable step forward for our students and a great opportunity for our community to get involved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you to all those who helped this project come to completion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're very excited to have the studio integrated once again with the high school where it all began.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The voice of Medford will be heard again on the airways and it is so important to tell the story through the eyes of the people, not necessarily the professionals.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I look forward to the success of our new community media center.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Can you hear me?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Much better.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Ward 6 and the Democratic Ward and City Committee, Griffin, for being here tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much for offering us this forum in order to speak to you and the general public.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My name is Stephanie Muccini-Burke, and I'm a candidate for re-election for the Office of Mayor for the City of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm the proud daughter of Lee, who's in our audience, and my dad, George, and we grew up on First Street in Wellington.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My husband, Brian, and I have three beautiful children.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've been married 31 years, and all of our kids attended public schools and went on to college.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford has been a wonderful place to raise our family, and it's why we choose to stay here each and every day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is our home.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: After graduating from Medford High School, I attended Suffolk University.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I commuted there every day and worked two jobs in order to put myself through.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Those years were filled with learning, and the greatest lesson was that there is no substitution for hard work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: At Suffolk, I received a Bachelor of Science in Business with a major in Accounting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: After graduating, I was hired at a Big 8 accounting firm.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was then that I earned my CPA license.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I then went on to Bentley University evenings while working and obtained my master's in taxation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When Brian and I began our family, I changed career paths and I started my own business right in Medford Square on Forest Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was called Rycon Financial, named after my two boys at the time, and did I know I was going to have a little girl, I probably would have changed the name, but I didn't at that point.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I learned especially what goes on in Medford Square at that time after spending 10 years on Forest Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was while self-employed that I felt I had a need that I had to get involved with the City Council.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I participated in local government.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I thought it was very important.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the people of Medford honored me by electing me to serve 15 long years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we worked really, really hard during those 15 years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This was followed by five years as the Director of Personnel and Budget for the City of Medford under Mayor McGlynn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then in 2015, I was elected by the people to be Medford's mayor, one of the proudest days of my life.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Anyone visiting our city these days would quickly know that it is an election year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You know what that means.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Candidates using buzzwords and slogans, asking for support of you, the voter.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We hear it from this one, vote for me and I'll do this, or vote for me and I'll do that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I am sure that you will not mind if I spare you the slogans and buzzwords because you deserve more than that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You deserve a clear description of my accomplishments as mayor and my hopes for the next two years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: After all, each of you wants the same thing that I want.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We want a Medford that can be the greatest it can be.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So when I say to you that I will be accountable, it's not a slogan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is my acknowledgment that the work of government is never done alone.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is never the work of one person.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We live in a democracy and we work in collaboration with each other, and that is why I call each of you a partner in progress.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As I stated, I'm a certified public accountant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My professional experience has brought me a deep understanding of the value of managing assets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is second nature to me.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And simply put, a well-managed city is one where the resources and assets of the city are identified, needs are assessed, and needs are fulfilled.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As we all know, this requires funding.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My administration has and will continue to be a responsible steward of our taxpayers' hard-earned dollars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We will continue to aggressively pursue grant funding to leverage our dollars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford's high quality bond rating is no accident.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's the result of careful planning and a prudent expenditure of municipal funds to projects that better our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Just today, we were listed as a top 10 list of most successful cities by Zipia.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're quite proud of that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My administration has also been accountable where the rubber meets the road, literally through the Complete Streets Initiative, which we brought into the city of Medford within three months of me being sworn into office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have moved forward to repave and fix major roads throughout every section of the city, which will make it safer for pedestrians, bicyclists, and vehicles.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our infrastructure needs are continually being addressed through the efforts of our Department of Public Works.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am proud of tackling the issues of the need of a new police station head-on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: For years, the rundown condition of the police department headquarters has been known.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: For years, this one condition was not adequately addressed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I did not choose to look in the rearview mirror and ask why.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Rather, I have chosen to look forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Because the starting point of all success is action, not blame.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So my administration initiated the process to build a new state-of-the-art police station.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've been meeting weekly now for over three months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a team that's comprised of our police chief, our city engineer, our environmentalist, as well as members of the police squad from all levels.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: men, female, that have been visiting police stations around our state and around our area to find out what's the best and what's the worst.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What do we like?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What do we want our station to have so that we do it right once, not have to go back and make changes two years down the road because it's the police headquarters that simply doesn't work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our fine law enforcement personnel deserve nothing less, as they serve the safety needs of our residents every hour of every day of every night.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In the world in which we live, safety can never be taken for granted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The needs of our public safety employees are many, and they must continually be addressed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have done just that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In year one of our five-year capital plan, the city has purchased 12 new police cruisers, breathing apparatus and turnout gear for our firefighters, new trucks and equipment for our DPW employees.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: However, public safety and public health is more than new equipment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is the converging of all departments and levels of government to come together to fight an epidemic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Of course, I'm speaking of the opioid crisis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Every Medford family stands shoulder to shoulder with each other in the fight against this reality.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When one of our families suffers, we all suffer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So to assist in this fight and augment the public services already in place, I did hire a full-time recovery coach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: For the first time, there's someone who has a specific purpose to work within our community, along with various agencies.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Marion Ryan, our district attorney, has monthly forums up at the Lawrence Memorial Hospital, where she brings together public health officials, City of Medford employees, police, fire from a multitude of communities to talk about this issue and to determine best practices.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is already being done today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is a disease that is so decimating to so many, especially our young people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Sometimes the quality of life in our city can oftentimes be measured by the spaces that we gather as a community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This truth has not been lost on me.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It started with the rehabilitation of this beautiful building that we gather in today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Celebrating its 80th birthday, I might tell you, WPA project, and we're very proud, and there's a birthday party next Thursday evening, so come on down.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, we've been partnering with the Metropolitan Area Planning Council and with the input of residents and business owners.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've engaged in a collaborative effort to plan for the revitalization of Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This plan will not be put on a shelf.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This plan will be implemented.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I guarantee it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And this has resulted in a goal of a mixed-use zone to live, work, and play, a plan for bicycle accessibility, safer streetscapes, connectivity of our pathways, and refocusing on our jewel, the mighty Mystic River.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In addition, work has begun on the Riverside Plaza project.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is an effort to transform a portion of Medford Square into a multi-use space to allow residents to engage in passive recreation or simply enjoy a community event.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Sense of community and quality of life go hand in hand.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We need these community spaces in order to do that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Investment in a city also means to put its resources to their optimal use.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have done just that with the hidden gem, the Chevalier Theater.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: By hiring a professional management company, Bill Blumenreich presents of the Wilbur Theater, to promote the Chevalier and to serve not only as a catalyst for arts and culture, but also as well as economic development in our Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This long overdue effort will create jobs, opportunities for our current and future small businesses, and provide an exciting new venue for first class entertainment in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is my hope that these efforts will not simply transform brick and mortar, but have an impact on the enjoyment of life for all of the residents of this city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am equally proud to shape the creation of a new full-time recreation department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This need has gone unaddressed in our community, and now we will have a department that will serve the recreational needs of Medford residents of all ages, young to old.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And when I hear the people say that our students are our future, I say that is an understatement.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I say that they are our potential and that we need to serve that potential now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am most proud of the work undertaken in support, supporting our expanded educational opportunities in our public schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Example of these new programs at Medford High include environmental studies, engineering, robotics, and a host of AP classes, a new media center that we're having a get together on this coming Sunday, as well as a brand new culinary arts restaurant, Bistro 489, that will be opening in November.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With these uplifting programs, our talented teachers, and most importantly, supportive parents, Medford's future has never looked brighter.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Each of these efforts is aimed at one goal, to make our city a vibrant community where everyone, young to senior, in the richness of our diversity, can fulfill their definition of neighborhood, their hopes for their children and family, in a safe, fully inclusive, participatory, and democratic fashion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are a welcoming city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Being mayor is more than offering a slogan or a buzzword.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's living up to the promise to serve every single day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whether it be arts and culture, constituent service, or spending time with your children at school, I more than enjoy serving Medford as its mayor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a hard job, but one that I love, because every day brings new opportunity to work in collaboration with the fine people of our city, young to senior again, to implement the Medford of tomorrow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My education, experience, knowledge of government, and deep commitment to this city is demonstrated daily.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am very proud of our first term accomplishments, but there is more work to be done.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Please allow me the opportunity and the honor of serving you as your mayor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I humbly request that you vote for me.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cast your vote on November 7th for Stephanie Muccini-Burke.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Please, let's continue to be partners in progress.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you and God bless.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's called the Cotton Swab Challenge, and I hereby challenge Mayor Curtatone of Somerville, Mayor Dolan of Melrose, and Mayor Christensen of Malden.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Take the challenge, make the pledge, come on, make it happen.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Together we can save a life, together we can be a match.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you everybody for coming here today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are so elated and excited to be welcoming Bill Blumenreich to this beautiful theater.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This really is a proud day for the city of Medford and just a little history of this building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was built in 1939.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's named for the remarkable World War I veteran.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Godfrey Chevalier, so we know that that name stands proudly and represents all of us as Americans.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This theater has hosted John F. Kennedy, Frank Sinatra, and Leroy, so we have some high expectations for this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're so very excited to be partnering with you to allow this theater to live up to its expectations, to have a grand flagship of Medford Square, and a critical component and a catalyst for the Medford Square Revitalization.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we are very, very thrilled to have them on the board.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I need to acknowledge some of the members of the committee that worked on this process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As we all know, we did the second RFP back last spring.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we put together a team, a highly qualified team, to make sure that this was a positive experience and a positive result in the end.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Leading it off is Mark Rumley, our city solicitor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: commission members that worked very hard each and every step of the way to make sure that this RFP was what we needed and what we wanted for the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With us today is John Costas, the chair of the Chivalry Commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mike Oliver is not present today, but he also worked very hard on this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He would have been the third commission member on this committee that we put together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're also lucky to have in attendance today City Council President Rick Caraviello,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: spent on this RFP.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Paul Solano, I'm a commission member as well, so thank you Paul.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Countless hours were spent on this RFP and I know by the faces in this room that many of you haven't heard those countless hours right down to pretty much this morning.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're just really thrilled that we were able to pull it all together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And my deepest thanks go out for a job well done by all involved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I further want to thank the endless devotion of past members of the Chevalier Commission that began in 1981, and friends of the Chevalier, especially Geraldine Brandy, who put her heart and soul into this building, and she made it a beautiful gem for this city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I know she's looking down on us, too, so very, very proudly today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So a thank you to our friend Geraldine upstairs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a few of the friends here today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have Nate Mockerbrack, we have Cindy Watson, and we also have Russ that also worked very hard to make sure that this place stayed up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think it was blood, sweat, and tears for a lot of you, and we've seen it each and every day, and you've never let down.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you all for the hard work that you've done over the course of the tenure of this beautiful building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So now, the highlights of the agreement.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The contract is comprised of four five-year terms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Bill Bloomberg will furnish to the City of Medford $1 for each ticket sold that will go into a restoration fund for the Chevalier Theatre.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the money that we've taken as a city is going to be reused again and again and again to make enhancements to this building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hiring Medford residents is a priority, and up to 15 performances per year will be free for the City of Medford to have.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So those are really great kudos, and thank you for allowing us to work back into the agreement that's at hand today, and we'll be signing shortly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also, we all know that we have the Boys and Girls Clubs just below us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They will continue to have a home.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we are very proud that we were able to work through this agreement, continue to be able to allow the services that the Boys and Girls Club offer to our community, and for children in need.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're just really thrilled that we were able to make this whole thing happen and blend it and work in harmony.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now, I would like to just welcome Joan Costa up to say a few words on behalf of the commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: has been out in the community over the past several months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So he's taken, he met with our friends group, so they could get to know them and their philosophy for the theater.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's met with business owners, he met with Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So he's hit the ground running already.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think at this point, we really need to find these contracts, and we can make

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you may realize, a year and a half ago, the citizens of Medford voted to adopt the CPA Act, which allows for monies to be put in a trust fund and spent for certain purposes, affordable housing, open space, and historic preservation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have with us two members tonight that would like to explain it so that the public can become more aware of this program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you may realize, a year and a half ago, the citizens of Medford voted to adopt the CPA Act, which allows for monies to be put in a trust fund and spent for certain purposes, affordable housing, open space, and historic preservation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have with us two members tonight that would like to explain it so that the public can become more aware of this program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have Joan Sear a member and Roberta Cameron is the chairperson of the committee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there's nine students from Lumiere.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Rivers Edge is along the Malden River, it runs from Wellington Station to Malden Station.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a new development, it's commercial and residential.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Those are the condos that are, those are directly behind, if you're on 16 looking at the mall to the right.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm pretty sure.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're the condos.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cabot Road.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's down Wellington Circle as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's brand new, so this is just, it's probably, it's just beginning, it has its occupancy starting up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's the towers at Riverside Ave.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The Alicante Rink, is that it?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yeah, so 1979 they've been there since.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As far as buildings, what are the buildings, you know, when you go down 9th Street at the end, there's a new... That's the one that, the five cabin is the brand new one that's having like a ribbon cutting in a week or so, but they have started their occupancy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The one before the train tracks, they're under 150 units.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He looked at 150 as a threshold.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So could I?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Really, for a true comparison, you should be looking at the Rivers Edge Drive.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's brand new.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's apartments that are built, you know, they haven't been existing for a very long time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the station landing would be next up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they were put in in 2004.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But they were part of like transit development, smaller units.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So those are probably the ones I would be looking at, but comparable about going forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This cabinet will be coming online.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay, so even, yeah.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So moved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On the motion, this report be updated for the first meeting in January.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Aye.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So at this point, if we could just entertain a quick little diversion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I don't know how many of you realize, but over the course of the last week, we've been collecting sporting goods equipment to send down to the Houston area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We realized how they were devastated and a lot of people were giving blood, donating money, and doing all sorts of things to help them out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our head baseball coach, Mike Nestor, came up with an idea and he said, why don't we do a drive?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These kids want to get back.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They have no equipment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everything's been just ruined.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So he wanted to start a drive for it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Jack Dempsey has put together this awesome video that is on a truck right now rolling into Texas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it's just really spectacular how the community came together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A lot of the sporting teams and the sporting equipment stores that supply our players with their equipment came through and put so many things on this truck.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's just simply amazing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So without further ado, I hope you all enjoy this video that Jack and the team put together with all the kids at the high school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hello, my name is Stephanie Muccini-Burke.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm the mayor of Medford, Mass., home of the mighty Medford Mustangs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They say up here in Medford country that our veins bleed blue and white, and we know you're the same.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're here to support you in rebuilding your community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm here with our athletic director, Bobby Maloney, and our head baseball coach, Mike Nestor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Bobby, would you like to say a few words?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we want to thank the Teamsters 25 for trucking down all of the items that we collected over the course of the last week.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They all were there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All the teams came.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And be it resolved that the school committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Joseph DiNucci.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. DiNucci was the state auditor for the Commonwealth of Mass for 24 years, a former state representative and championship boxer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I don't know how many of you realize, but over the course of the last week, we've been collecting sporting goods equipment to send down to the Houston area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We realized how they were devastated, and a lot of people were giving blood, donating money, and doing all sorts of things to help them out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our head baseball coach, Mike Nestor, came up with an idea, and he said, why don't we do a drive?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These kids want to get back.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They have no equipment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everything's been just ruined.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So he wanted to start a drive for it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Jack Dempsey has put together this awesome video that is on a truck right now rolling into Texas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it's just really spectacular how the community came together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A lot of the sporting teams and the sporting equipment stores that supply our players with their equipment came through and put so many things on this truck.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's just simply amazing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On the motion that a report be submitted with the numbers that some of our larger developers have submitted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Aye.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mayor Burke?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Skerry had a point of information.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: No, they didn't say 700.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was 400 and something, but it's in the land court.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Appeals have been filed in the land court.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: No decisions have been made by any judge on any of the issues pending there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there approximately 40 on the wait list, or is it higher?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But that means that this is a paper that we received tonight that we have not been able to review yet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: OK.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: No, actually, I think it's quite important.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's been a lot of discussion about it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think the public needs to know, the parents need to know, what are we doing to make changes at the McGlynn, to beef it up so that there's more of a demand for that middle school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I think it's very important that we talk about it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I just have one follow up question.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I didn't get to ask.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm sorry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: School committee resolutions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medgar School Committee expresses some safe condolences to the family of Joan Gorman.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Gorman was the mother of school committee member, Erin DiBenedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Carl Galusi.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Murray was the godfather of city employee Lisa Caticcio and uncle of school committee member Erin DiBenedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If we could all rise for a moment of silence on the passing of these residents and relatives.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion to adjourn?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cugno.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Congratulations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Congratulations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much for coming tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Did you say motion to adjourn?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for this press conference.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We wanted to give some updates about our community so that everybody's aware of what's going on in the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am lucky enough to be here this morning.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have President Caraviello, we have Councilor Knight, Councilor Scarpelli, and Councilor Dello Russo.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you all for joining us today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have with us as well many department heads and members of the press.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: First off, we're in budget season right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As people may realize, it's night four of budget hearings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And this year we were really proud to deliver a budget that was full of additional services being offered to the community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: First being a recreation, full-time recreation department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've had a study group that has been working on this since well before January.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they came through with many recommendations and a survey to determine what do the people of Medford want from us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we came up with a plan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a lot of people that have supported it and they're really eager to see this budget go through so that we can start the hiring process to have a full-time rec director, an assistant director, as well as people working to staff the rec department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Councilor Scarpelli was integral to the whole process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He spearheaded the group that had the meeting weekly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: George, if you'd like to say a few words about it, we'd be more than happy to have you come up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We do have a summer break program here, our guide for city recreation so please pick up a copy at the library, city hall, throughout the city and get online and sign up for some of these amazing classes that are being offered.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Secondly, I just actually left Tufts University for an opioid conference and we're proud to be supportive of the efforts in trying to fight this addiction that's out there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With that being said, we are appointing in the budget, we've asked for a recovery coach to be put into our budget.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think it's really important for someone to be on the ground, really meeting with the people on a regular basis, and coming up with solutions to this problem, this epidemic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So with that, I also have initiated a position in the budget for that, so we're really eager to see this budget take off on July 1st, so that we can augment services to our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: the library.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's probably the most beloved asset in our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And not only have we met the state guidelines for funding, but we've augmented those funding recommendations to the City Council.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're about $100,000 over what is required of us, but with that we are increasing one more position so that we can have a media technology specialist at the library to help all of the people in Medford, from youth to senior citizens,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: so that they can have access to some of the latest and greatest opportunities online, with media, as well as on tape, and the various opportunities to have books on your phone and whatnot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled about that, and we've also increased the library's part-time budget so that we can have additional staff on hand to help the citizens of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lastly, we have increased, we've offered a traffic engineer position.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you watched any of the city council meetings over the last six months to a year,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You'll see that there's been a cry out for a traffic engineer on staff that can address some of the development that's going on as well as development in other communities, specifically the Malden Hospital site.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really proud, based upon this collaboration that we've formed, very strong collaboration, that we have put a traffic engineer in the engineering department for the upcoming budget cycle.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled about that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And our police department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Chief Sacco, I've been involved in this budget, barring the year when I took a little hiatus, for the last seven years and each and every year Chief Sacco has asked for crime scene technologists,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and an information technologist.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled that we have put those positions into his police budget for this upcoming year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that just augments the services that are offered.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It allows our police officers to be out in the streets and doing the job that they're tasked to do while someone else can pick up the load and perform all of those technical jobs that are mandated in police departments of today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really eager about that as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lastly, our school department in the budget is about $2.1 million over last year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Some of it is in negotiated salaries, but also we know there's a need in our schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We still call them the new schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But they were in 2001, they were dedicated, and there's a need for increased maintenance.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we've met with parents, we've met with school boards, you know, PTOs, and all of them have come out and said, we need more maintenance money, we need to be able to keep the school's spick and span.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and address some of the smaller things that are so very important for the children of our community as well as the parents that peruse our schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're increasing the budget line for maintenance in our schools by $200,000 strictly for supplies and repairs and also we're hoping to get a position on that as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled with this budget.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think it's very comprehensive.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We feel that we've listened to the needs, the issues that have been raised at city council meetings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and from our department heads, so we really feel like we're addressing the needs of our community through these various outlets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much for your support, thank you for the budget hearings, and for bringing good ideas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Like I've said before, good ideas come from anyone, anywhere, and we're open to them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So keep on keeping on, bring them up to us and we certainly will evaluate them and move forward to the best we can within budgetary constraints.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Secondly, it's come up in the council as well, Mr. Gabb and our zoning.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As many may realize, our zoning really hasn't been updated since we did the station landing project.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That was our mixed-use zoning that we developed for that particular Wellington area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think it's a good zoning, write-up of zoning.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: However, it doesn't always fit into other areas of the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm really proud to announce that we are receiving $40,000 to conduct a zoning review of Mystic Avenue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: $10,000 of that is through MAPC with the DLTA grant, as well as $30,000 from the Mass Housing Trust.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled with that, and I think Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Councilor Knight would like to come up and say a few words about zoning.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's a member of the Zoning Committee, along with Councilor Dello Russo and Councilor Fatlow-Chiazat.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's no bigger supporter of job creation than the councillors that sit on the Zoning Subcommittee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I thank you for all of your service.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we want to see commercial development as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's not just about housing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's about commercial.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: bringing jobs to our city, which we feel strongly about.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that's one step in that direction, and we look forward to many more occurring that way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the Medford Square process that we've been undergoing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're getting draft reports back now from MNPC.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you know, we did a $90,000 grant study that paid for all the services.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They did a lot of outreach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've had community meetings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've had vision boards.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and they're now ready to come back in with their recommendations for zoning for Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Actually, our zoning is okay for Medford Square, but what we have written into it is setbacks and lot lines, and that's what's deterring from development in Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really eager to fine-tune and finesse the zoning of Medford Square, and we'll be working with the council on that as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: City Hall, we all know City Hall is under construction right now and we have a schedule of renovations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So basically the roof and the parapet will be done in the first week of July.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They'll begin the council chamber work at the end of July, which we're really eager about.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We want to get that room, it's the people's room, we want to get it up looking really fine and nice and we want it to be used by the people on an ongoing basis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a beautiful building, it will be turning 80 years old in September, and it was a fine time for us to do some improvements to this gorgeous building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Phase 3 is up front, which began in earnest at the beginning of May, and they're very much underway.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have some sketches, we have one sketch there and one behind.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: that show what it will look like, but it will be a much more friendlier, handicapped accessible facility.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It certainly will be an open area where we can have summer concerts and community events like Circle the Square that's kicking off this Thursday, so make sure you come down to Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we're really eager to get this project finished so that we can give her an 80th birthday party, hopefully beginning of October sometime.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So stay tuned.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's another item that we kicked off last January.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was a senior work-off abatement process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We feel that our seniors should be brought into City Hall.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We really want to collaborate with them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They bring so much to the table.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have opened up a new round that will be beginning in July as well for the senior work-off abatement.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Last year we had 35 seniors that came to work here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they're able to work, earn about $1,500 that go against their tax bill.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's a win-win for us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They pleasure us with their smiles each and every day, and they in turn get an abatement on their taxes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled with the outcome from last year, and we're eager to get it off the ground again for this upcoming fiscal year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're getting applications, so please come into room 204.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Fill out an application and we will find something that works for both sides so that we get the benefit of your history, your education, and your strengths in the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we in turn, we get greeters that welcome people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think people feel really good when they walk into this building now because they're greeted with a smile and they're not walking around randomly trying to find an office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled with the program and we look forward to its expansion in the upcoming fiscal year, 18.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Summer Rec, we touched upon it a little bit.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We do have the guide out, so please make sure you check it out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's lots of opportunities for enrichment as well as just summer fun.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have our park program kicking off in the second week, third week of July.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It'll be a six week program and it'll be moving throughout the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So everyone will be coming to the park.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the kids will get to meet each other.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that when they do go to middle school, they have friends that they've already met through our summer youth program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're really excited about that and it was part and parcel of Constance Scarpelli's as well as people on the rec committee that worked hard as well as activists from our office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Veterans Wall, moving right along.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are going to be dedicating it on June 25th on Emerald Park at 10am.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are collaborating with the Elks Club that does an annual Flag Day event.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We thought it'd be a nice day to join forces and do something for our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's about 40 names that will be entered upon the wall at Honor Roll Park and we urge you to come on out and support those people that have fought for our freedoms, fought for our flag, and allow us to be here today to do what we do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And finally, something that I'm really saddened by, our illustrious Diane McLeod, our diversity director, is retiring.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Actually, today is her final day of service in the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She has been with us for 24 years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She, tears coming, don't make me cry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She has done so much for this community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She has worked so very hard with outreach and collaboration and conversations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Diane has really done it all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's been a really tough, I know, a tough month for her to get to this point.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She's been trying to tick and time, go over lists and make sure nothing falls through the cracks because this really has been her baby.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She was our first diversity director and she's done a fantastic job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're really proud to call her friend.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We were proud to have her in the city of Medford and she brought her wealth and her knowledge to the city and she will be missed for sure.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But in her last days,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Diane was able to pull off a grant in the amount of $130,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So Diane, take it away.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The first time the Mass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everyone in this building loves dining in as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So of course when Diane announced that she would be leaving the great city of Medford for retirement and to spend time with her family and she has two weddings coming up with her two boys and I know she's a proud mama and she's really excited about those opportunities for her to continue and to have a golfer by the way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's been a lot of calls I've received in my office, a lot from the Human Rights Commission, people have just been calling and saying

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What are you going to do?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: How are we going to do this?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We need someone from Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We need someone that knows Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We need someone that shows diversity in every aspect of their life.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So, and with those calls have come many recommendations, mainly for this one individual.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're really thrilled to have him here with us today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: His name is Mr. Neil Osborne.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Neil, you can stand up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Neil has served on various commissions throughout the city from planning board to the human rights commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's chair of the NAACP, president of the NAACP.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He is just a person that is out in the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He knows the issues we're facing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know that he will embrace all that we have to offer and to make our city, we have a great city here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a welcoming city here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we know that Neil is going to add to that and really bring in everyone so that there's a comfort level.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everyone feels safe, especially in these times that we're dealing with right now on the federal level.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's an attorney by trade.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's done a lot with personnel issues.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'm sure Neil can elaborate a little bit more about his experience.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'd like to welcome him to the City of Medford's department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To the department head.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I have complete faith in Neil's abilities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And like he said, we'll probably be calling Diane.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're going to give her the wedding time off.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But probably come August, we're going to be tapping in.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We know it's a big transition.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We understand what transitions are all about.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Come on now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We just took office a year and a half ago.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we know what it's like.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we know that Diane will be there, as she has been, there to support our administration.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you're going to be missed, my dear.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Definitely going to be missed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So with that, I will end this press conference.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And stay tuned.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In a couple of weeks, we'll have another one on some more updates.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have some more grants that we're waiting to get solidified and to make some big announcements.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So stay tuned.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And now we over and out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good evening everyone, and thank you for joining us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm here live from the Medford Community Cable Station, the new facility that was just built, and it's an honor to be here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm Mayor Stephanie McShaney-Burke, and I'd just like to give you a community update on some important events that have happened over the past several weeks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And please excuse me, I have a little bit of a hoarse voice.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But this really is an honor to open up the studio.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you may realize, we've been working on it for several months now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it has just about completed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're waiting for some additional cameras to be delivered.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we'll also be performing interviews for the station manager starting tomorrow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very excited to get this underway and also to eventually open it up to the public, which is the main important goal of this studio.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as you know, during the day it will be used by our Medford High School students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're getting a double whammy for our money here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really, really thrilled about that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Secondly, I want to bring up someone from Armstrong Ambulance.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have Daniel Roba here representing the company.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You may realize that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts mandated that affected in September, we have

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have devices on the fields for all of our sports teams.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With that called out, we knew we wanted to jump on it a little earlier.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We wanted to get them onto the fields as soon as we possibly could.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we reached out to our partner, Armstrong Ambulance, to see if they'd be willing to donate some of the defibrillators for us for the fields.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And of course, as Armstrong has always done, they've always stood tall and they've always come to our aid.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really, really thrilled to have them with us today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Daniel, maybe you can give a little summary on the number.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much, Danielle.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Please send our sincere thanks to the Armstrong family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As I said, they've been fabulous partners with us just last Thursday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They were up at City Hall training parents on how to use

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: different devices and how to perform CPR.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they're always there and they always come through.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you again on behalf of the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We appreciate it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Second up, we would like to announce that the Cummings Foundation has awarded the Medford Public Schools a $100,000 grant over three years to support the work of our Center for Citizenship and Social Responsibility.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have with us tonight Richard Trotter who would like to highlight some of the accomplishments of this program and then we would like to bring up Cummings Foundation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Trotter.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you may realize, the Cummings Foundation gives out 100 for 100.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's 100 grants of $100,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's just an amazing feat, and hopefully you all caught the globe this morning.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was a wonderful story on the family, of the Cummings family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're really proud to have with us David Blumberg here today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Not to be confused with Mr. Bloomberg, who is instrumental.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's a Medford resident.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's been instrumental in helping us garner this grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we welcome you, Mr.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With that, thank you very much and congratulations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Dave and his lovely wife, Gwen, don't live too far from here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I hope that they'll come up and visit the center on one of your next events so that you can experience where the funding and what the funding does for us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Next up, I would like to introduce Mary Ann O'Connor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She's the director of our public health department for the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And she works hand in hand with the school department on a host of different issues.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're just really thrilled to have her here tonight so she can tell you a little bit about some of the work that's going on, especially regarding opiate addiction.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we'd like her to say a few words and show a product that's going to be coming out in the very near future.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mary Ann.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Mary Ann.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also under Mary Ann's leadership, we've been very active in hosting a series of events at City Hall and the school department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One of which just transpired over this past weekend and it was called In Plain Sight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I hope many of the parents got to experience that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's really amazing the lengths that companies are going to, to give children and young adults a means of hiding some of their uses.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was eye-opening for me to walk through there and see some of the gadgets that look like generic items.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You can't hear a spray, but it has something that you twist off and then it's a hollow

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: inside for storage of things and different types of regular everyday tools that can be used for other purposes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it was really eye-opening to me.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I thank you for putting that on and I know you had a stream of parents that came through the building last week in addition to the CPR training that Armstrong conducted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it was a nice segue and a nice cooperation that occurred over the last several days at City Hall.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you, Mary Ann.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I just want to make one quick announcement.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think it's really important that we take a stand on opiate addiction and that we put everything we can into it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you may realize, a few years ago, we dedicated funds for a full-time coordinator, outreach prevention coordinator, and that has worked famously.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: However, we think more is needed, and we have put in the budget for a position for a coach, so a recovery coach that can actually get in the community,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And deal one on one with the individuals that are afflicted to try and help them through that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're hopeful that the city council will see that that's an important item as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we look forward to that passage.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I make that announcement tonight that the administration is completely committed to fighting this horrible epidemic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Marianne.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We also have Tony Vento with us tonight from the school department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She likewise received a grant having to do with opioids.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'd like Tony to just describe it a little bit.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you can tell, the schools in the city have been really, really busy over the last several months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We try to get as many grants as we can.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We certainly are writing them on a daily basis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Tony has been very successful.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So tell us a little bit about your grant, Tony.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you can see, we're not just starting in on this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've been active in this topic for several years now, and we're just really pushing the envelope and trying to do as much as we can to curb some of the issues and to cease the stigma that surrounds opioid addiction.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Bento.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Another grant that we just received has to do with vocational services.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a regional grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a regionalization of service grants from the Lieutenant Governor's office in the amount of $45,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: People may be aware that we have a wonderful vocational program and certainly Heidi Ruccio, who has been the director of it for several years now, has been instrumental in changing the look and the feel of our vocational studies.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She certainly has expanded programming and brought in a wealth of fabulous instructors that work day to day with the students and we now have crossover between the high school and the vocational program so that the kids can go back and forth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our vocational students are able to take college prep classes and likewise our college bound students and business students are able to cross over and take culinary arts for example.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's a really wonderful marriage, and we really tried hard to create this synergy between the two schools to make it one, which we have applied to the state to be known as one cohesive school district.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we are very thankful to the Lieutenant Governor's office, and Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Buccio would like to come up and say a few words about that grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Sergio.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And this $45,000 grant piggybacks a half a million dollar grant that we received just a shot two months ago from the Lieutenant Governor and Governor's Office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lieutenant Governor Polito came to our school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She did a walking tour.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She got to see what we wanted the funds for.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they have been partners with us each and every step of the way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled with the Lieutenant Governor and Governor's commitment to vocational studies.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And part of the $500,000 is going towards our new culinary arts program, which we're very proud of and we hope to have finished over the summer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think a piece of that has to do with Wynn coming to Everett.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We know Wynn Casinos is coming to Everett, and we're trying to look at the positives that will be coming from that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And part of that, our job creation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really trying to get our students that they can be ready and able when the job market demands it, which we know will be in a short few years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And what we hear out in the marketplace is that Wynn is going to gobble up a lot of the employees that may be working elsewhere as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we need to have a stream of students and accomplished people that are ready to fill the job market.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is going to be several voids across the Commonwealth, especially in the Boston area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled about that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And again, we want to send our thanks out to the governor's office for their support and commitment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ruccio, we will be missing her in a very short while as she goes up to Essex.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And she surely will be missed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She has turned the school around and put it on a road.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that's certainly a road that we continue to follow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: be reaching those strides.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we are thankful for all of her years of service to the city of Medford and we wish her the best of luck out there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The last item is that we have a recreation guide that just went live last week.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we want parents to know that we have a really robust program for the summer months coming up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we urge you to either come by, pick up a copy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're at the library.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're at the schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a little backpack slip that's gone home for you to know that it's around.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And certainly up on the website, you can see the entire PDF.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I urge parents and family members to reach out and look at the programming that we have over the summer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then to augment that, we have had a recreation committee that's been working diligently for the last several months, greater than six months now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they have come up with a survey that has reached out to the entire metro population to see what would you like to see in your recreation department with the goal of going full-time in the very near future.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm really proud to say that we have incorporated a budget account for a full-time recreation department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It will be delivered to the city council tomorrow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we're really thrilled to be able to say that we are committed to a full-time recreation program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And likewise, we understand that if we keep our kids safe and we keep our kids busy, we want to keep them on that healthy road, whether it be physical health, mental health, and the whole nine yards.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really committed to that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And recreation goes well beyond our children.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It certainly goes all the way up to our seniors.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we look forward to having a rec coordinator and program director on board, hopefully by September.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they'll be looking at programming across the spectrum so that we can really attack physical issues and mental health issues on an ongoing basis on behalf of the City of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And just one lighter touch, the Farmer's Market is coming back.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's opening up this Thursday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So hopefully, weather permitting, they'll be in operation and they have a new location down at the Condon Shell on Route 16.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I urge all of you to come out, come to the Farmer's Market.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a great, not only a great event just to socialize at with live music, but also get your fresh produce and really come down and help the local businesses that need your help, the local farmers.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So with that being said, I thank you for coming to this press conference and I do appreciate

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: the ongoing efforts of all of the department heads and the school department and the private partners that we have built partnerships with.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Certainly we couldn't do half of what we do without the volunteers that really step forward and help us get things done in the City of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm thankful and grateful and I look forward to a future press conference where we can announce more information on the City of Medford activities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and a couple of announcements.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yeah, graduation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This says 11.30.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: 11 o'clock, okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cugno, did you have a comment?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to adjourn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Investments in our school children continue today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Augmented security measures in our centers would not be possible without the collaboration with our public safety professionals.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Safety is a core component to an individual's comfort in and desire to be in a community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have invested in state-of-the-art self-contained breathing apparatus for our firefighters and a second set of turnout gear.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Medford City Council for voting that last night, for supporting this initiative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These are to provide the most current apparatus for firefighters' safety and ultimately for your safety.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nine new firefighters graduated the academy last month and one entered this past Monday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are working hard to keep up with retirements by accelerating the civil service process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kudos to our Board of Health for receipt of a seven-year, 100,000 per year grant from the Mass Department of Public Health Bureau of Substance Abuse to provide opiate abuse prevention services for six cities and towns in our area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We all understand the impact this drug has on our society, and we are making every effort to raise awareness, erase the stigma, and provide assistance for those suffering from addiction, as well as support for their families.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have formed a team approach under Mary Ann O'Connor, who recently came to us in the last several months, for our prevention and outreach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have an outreach manager, a recovery coach, we work with Lawrence Morell Hospital, and the police department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Every life matters, and we thank our police and firefighters for volunteering to administer NACAN in this cause.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And while we are not to clear the trust at Citi, be assured that our police department protocols do not allow for profiling.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Witnesses and victims are not asked about their immigration status.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So be sure and ask your lawyer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you can ask me what the question posed to me most often,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I would have to say, it's when are we getting a new police station?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I hear day in and day out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And today, just this morning, I announced that we will be submitting a loan order to the city council next week on February 14th, requesting funds to commission an architect to begin the plans for a new station.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have turned the city upside down looking for a new location.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've toured commercial spaces.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've contacted property owners.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Property owners have contacted us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And in the end, the right location with no land cost and no relocation during construction is the current site of the training facility on Main Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The current facility will be demolished, and the proposed 35,000 square foot, three-story new construction will house all amenities of the state-of-the-art resilient headquarters, including deserved equal space for our female and male officers, technology upgrades, and most importantly, safe interior space for our office's well-being.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Public safety investments continue today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In conclusion, this city of ours, this great city of ours, continues to move forward on a foundation built on dialogue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue that echoes in this building, allowing the voices of all residents to be heard with an attitude of inclusion and fairness.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue of renewal, where creative and imaginative ideas are brought forward to better the quality of life in our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue that resonates with the message that Medford is on the move, embracing a future of possibilities, embracing a future of hope.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On this night, in our beautiful City Hall, and I say that the state of our city is sound, it is stable, and it is sturdy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as your mayor, I stand as committed as ever to foster this dialogue with you as we continue to cultivate a city on which we can be partners in progress.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: God bless Medford, the commonwealth, and the United States of America.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you all very much for being here this evening, and good night, and be safe tomorrow with the upcoming blizzard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present, seven present, none absent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All please rise and salute our flag.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the republic for which it stands, one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Item one, approval of amended minutes of April 3rd, 2017.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion for approval by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cugno, seconded by Mr. Skerry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: April 3rd meeting?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They have ordered them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We just don't have a date of delivery yet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They do work very closely now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's way beyond a start.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've been spending a lot of money, a lot of commitment to this topic from a city perspective.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I know that Penny and her team, there's quite a few that are part of her team now, and they do outreach, they do coaching, they connect people with beds if need be to get them in for treatment, and the post.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there's a lot going on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What he's done differently now is he's actually going into the neighborhoods to host them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So people, a little more localized, but I believe it's Wednesday night at 6 at the senior center.
