[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Hagee was the mother of Carolyn Hagee, former administrative assistant to the superintendent and secretary to the school committee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have another item in the addendum.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee expresses sincere condolences to the family of Ahmed Azizi.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Azizi was a former Medford Public Schools custodian.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Could all please rise for a moment of silence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion to adjourn?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Vandekloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Bringing arts and culture to the forefront continues today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This winter, I signed on to the Metro Mayor's Medication Compact to become carbon neutral region-wide by 2050.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This raises environmental consciousness of every decision the city makes going forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To this end, we initiated the process last fall to purchase the street lights that are owned and managed by National Grid, with the goal to convert to LED over the summer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We anticipate savings in electricity usage, thus reducing environmental amendments, and based on direct maintenance by us of the lights, there will be a less than five year payback from converting to LED.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In addition, in collaboration with the city council, we are experimenting with increased lighting in Medford Square for our decorative lights.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Once finalized, we will fully install for a safer streetscape in our square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our Office of Environment has been hard at work to receive the following grants for additional projects.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: $250,000 from the Stanton Foundation to build a dog park at Riverbed Park, which will be built this spring.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And thank you, Class IV.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A grant from the Mass Coastal Zone Management for 125,000 to build the city's first green infrastructure to naturally clean storm water before it flows into the Mystic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is a partnership with the Mystic River Watershed Association, or MIRA as we refer to it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A partnership grant for the Clipper Ship Connector from DCR to design and engineer the half-mile multi-use path between Medford Square and River Bend Park.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is in partnership with Dr. Medford and Myra, and a generous donation from Wegmans for $23,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Wegmans!

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're not even in our city, and they're already contributing to these wonderful things, so we're very lucky to have them coming, and they expect construction to end by next October-November timeframe.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We received a green community grant, another green community grant for $250,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's for LED lighting in our schools, which will be installed over the next few weeks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These grants would not be possible without the hard work of the team in the energy environment under the leadership of Alicia Hunt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Alicia recently received the Mystic Municipal Leadership Award from the Mystic River Watershed Association.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much, Alicia, for all your hard work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I also want to thank Eagle Scout candidate, Calvin Lambert.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I believe he's in the audience.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Calvin.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're working with our environmental office and our Department of Public Works to build bridges around rice ponds and sensitive areas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much, Calvin, for your efforts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lastly, we have created the Go Green Medford Coalition, which will be an umbrella entity for all sustainability-minded groups in Medford to coordinate activities and track outcomes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Environmental focus continues today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As chairperson of the Medford School Committee, working with committee members, administration, and faculty, our public schools continue to make great achievements.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Examples include

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Increased access to career and technical education for Medford students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The integration of Medford High and Medford Voc Tech has enabled our students to simultaneously participate in both rigorous academics and occupational exploration skill development.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nine new Chapter 74 technical programs are now available.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Heidi, Riccio, and the students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Enrollment of ninth grade students in career tech education has doubled under her leadership.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've also secured over $1 million in new grants to revitalize our vocational technical learning environment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we've also captured out-of-district tuitions and generated new sources of regionalized revenue to support expansion of educational opportunities for our youth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have maintained a comprehensive curriculum that provides a full range of core academic subjects and specialized electives.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: MetroDOT has 16 Advanced Placement courses, among the most in the area, as well as a full complement of art, music, technology, foreign language, and health education programs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have two standout MetroDOT students with us tonight, Joseph Farrar and Kenny Toussaint.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Joseph, a Medford High School senior, took first place at the Massachusetts State Science and Engineering Fair in developing scientific models, while Kenny graduated last spring from Medford Tech and is currently enrolled in Massachusetts College of Pharmacy and Health Services.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As a little girl from Haiti, she left her homeland at the age of 11 with her dad.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She worked hard to learn the English language and excelled in her technical programs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kenny also earned college credits through a dual enrollment program at Buncombe Hill Community College.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Both of these young adults demonstrate the Medford Public Schools advantage, MPS advantage, in our commitment to you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have introduced before school programs at our elementary schools, while after school programs are growing exponentially.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They provide substantial coverage and constructive activities for students after regular hours.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are enhancing our programs and activities to provide inclusive opportunities for all students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In order to accomplish this, substantial professional development with an emphasis on social and emotional learning in our schools has been made.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have added counseling and behavior support staff to our teams.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lastly, we're recognized by the National School Board's Journal for School Security Practices.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have tightened security at all schools by adding staff and the Raptor ID system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Investments in our school children continue today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Augmented security measures in our schools would not be possible without collaboration with our public safety professionals.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Safety is a core component to an individual's comfort in and desire to be in a community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have invested in state-of-the-art self-contained breathing apparatus for our firefighters and a second set of turnout gear.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Medford City Council, for voting that last night for supporting this initiative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These are to provide the most current apparatus for firefighters' safety and ultimately for your safety.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nine new firefighters graduated the academy last month and one entered this past Monday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are working hard to keep up with retirements by accelerating the civil service process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kudos to our Board of Health for receipt of a seven-year, $100,000 per year grant from the Mass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Department of Public Health Bureau of Substance Abuse to provide opiate abuse prevention services for six cities and towns in our area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We all understand the impact this drug has on our society, and we are making every effort to raise awareness, erase the stigma, and provide assistance for those suffering from addiction, as well as support for their families.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have formed a team approach under Mary Ann O'Connor, who recently came to us in the last several months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: for prevention and outreach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have an outreach manager, a recovery coach, we work with Lawrence Memorial Hospital, and the police department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Every life matters, and we thank our police and firefighters for volunteering to administer NACAN in this cause.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And while we are not to clear the trust at City, be assured that our police department protocols do not allow for profiling.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Witnesses and victims are not asked about their immigration status.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So be sure and ask your lawyer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you can ask me what the question posed to me most often.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I would have to say it's when are we getting a new police station?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I hear day in and day out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And today, just this morning, I announced that we will be submitting a loan order to the city council next week on February 14th, requesting funds to commission an architect to begin the plans for a new station.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have turned this city upside down looking for a new location.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've toured commercial spaces.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've contacted property owners.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Property owners have contacted us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And in the end, the right location with no land cost and no relocation during construction is the current site of the training facility on Main Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The current facility will be demolished, and the proposed 35,000 square foot, three-story new construction will house all amenities at the state-of-the-art resilient headquarters, including deserved equal space for our female and male officers, technology upgrades, and most importantly, safe interior space for our office's well-being.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Public safety investments continue today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In conclusion, this city of ours, this great city of ours, continues to move forward on a foundation built on dialogue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue that echoes in this building, allowing the voices of all residents to be heard with an attitude of inclusion and fairness.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue of renewal, where creative and imaginative ideas are brought forward to better the quality of life in our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue that resonates with the message that Medford is on the move, embracing a future of possibilities, embracing a future of hope.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On this night, in our beautiful City Hall, and I say that the state of our city is sound, it is stable, and it is sturdy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as your mayor, I stand as committed as ever to foster this dialogue with you as we continue to cultivate a city on which we can be partners in progress.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: God bless America, the commonwealth, and the United States of America.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you all very much for being here this evening, and good night, and be safe tomorrow with the upcoming blizzard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good afternoon.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford is proud to support Team HEMO at Gillette Stadium on Sunday, June 4th.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our community has come together to raise awareness and join in the fight against pediatric cancer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm buzzing my hair for kids with cancer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm buzzing my head for kids with cancer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Alright guys, I'm gonna pray tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Let's give one more round for the audience before we leave.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Alright, I'm just gonna take out my competition now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The only competition I have, David Pagliaro.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good afternoon.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford is proud to support Team HEMO at Gillette Stadium on Sunday, June 4th.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our community has come together to raise awareness and join in the fight against pediatric cancer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm buzzing my hair for kids with cancer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The secretary will call the roll.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present, seven present, none absent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the republic for which it stands, one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's old business.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's the report on safe routes to school program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are really, really proud to announce that the Brooks School has received a $920,000 grant for Safe Routes to School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They have been working on this project for the last, I think, four years, if I'm correct.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they've worked very, very hard to demonstrate the

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: activity in the school, the need to get kids walking, the safe routes to get to school as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they've been really, really busy working on this, and we were so very proud to receive the letter from the Commonwealth of Mass, Department of Transportation, that we have been awarded this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know we have some parents in the audience that worked very, very hard that we would like to come up and say a few words about this, and then we can say thank you for all of your efforts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So Liz, would you like to come up?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Liz and your daughter?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could, Sarar is the Director of Mass in Motion for the City of Medford, so she gets involved with a lot of walking issues, healthy eating issues.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She does a lot of different things in the community, so we're very, very happy for all of her efforts as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So SORRA will be reaching out to all of the schools to get them on board, to get them really motivated to take on this task.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you did apply in 14, and we were just notified now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And when the state came out, they did a full assessment of the area of the Berks School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And literally from Placeton Road down Placeton all the way up to the Winthrop Street Rotary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they looked at a wide expanse of where all the kids are coming from.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the report is amazing, the detailed work that they put together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But they will be expanding.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're doing the Complete Streets project right at Alston and High, right at the corner of the Brooks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they're going to be expanding it up to Woburn Street and further down into the square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they're taking on some of the things that we're not able to do right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But $920,000 is a fabulous grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you so much, Liz and your team.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Great job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I also want to thank Principal Andrews.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was fantastic when we worked on this grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Great job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. DeVoe was a 1964 graduate of Medford High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they've worked very, very hard to demonstrate the activity in the school, the need to get kids walking, the safety

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: routes to get to school as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know we have some parents in the audience that worked very, very hard that we would like to come up and say a few words about this and then we can say thank you for all of your efforts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So Liz, would you like to come up?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Liz and your daughter?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could, Sarar is the Director of Mass in Motion for the City of Medford, so she gets involved with a lot of walking issues, healthy eating issues.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She does a lot of different things in the community, so we're very, very happy for all of her efforts as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So, Sarah will be reaching out to all of the schools to get them on board, to get them really motivated to take on this task.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you did apply in 14, and we were just notified now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And when the state came out, they did a full assessment of the area of the Brooks School, and literally from Placeton Road, down Placeton, all the way up to the Winthrop Street Rotary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they looked at a wide expanse of where all the kids are coming from.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the report is amazing, the detailed work that they put together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But they will be expanding.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're doing the Complete Streets project right at Alston and High, right at the corner of the Brooks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they're going to be expanding it up to Woburn Street and further down into the square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they're taking on some of the things that we're not able to do right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But $920,000 is a fabulous grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you so much, Liz and your team.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Great job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Maybe you can steal Liz and take her to some of your schools and she can show what she did.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So he was great in getting it started and now Principal Galussi will take it over and get it to completion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Great job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you for coming in.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Do you have any questions?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Stephen Honeycutt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Honeycutt was an active member of the community who served on the city's disabilities commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was a strong supporter of the Medford Public Schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Stephen DeVoe.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. DeVoe was the brother of former superintendent Phillip DeVoe.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. DeVoe was a 1964 graduate of Medford High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Frank Loschuto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Loschuto?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Loschuto was a former Medford Public Schools custodian for many years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And lastly, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Senator Kenneth Donnelly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Senator Donnelly lost his courageous battle with brain cancer this past Sunday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If we could all please rise and take a moment of silence on the passing of these individuals.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, there's one other item.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a report of committees which correlate to our item for old business, which was on our last school committee agenda.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We had a recommendation to formally approve the Medford High School, Medford Vocational Technical High School merger into one local education state code, LEA code, as you said during our meetings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if we could also take the committee of the whole report from last week.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We had Dr. Perrella and Dr. Riccio did a presentation last week describing the fundamental reasons for merging this LEA number and it has a host of benefits to us including some efficiencies, the ability to have one database for all students so that grading and scheduling can be done

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: in one spot as opposed to people having to shift from one program into another.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there was a motion at our committee, the whole, that we adopt the merger of the two into the one LE number.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And is there a motion to accept the committee report as presented?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good point.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Skerry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, how did they agree with you?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion to receive the committee report during that committee, the whole second seconded by all those in favor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The motion to accept the committee report as filed is so adopted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm now on the recommendation to formally approve the merger into one local education state code by Mr. Skerry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It should be efficiencies gained from it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good roll call vote on the formal acceptance of the combined LEA number for both schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And thank you to Dr. Riccio and Perella for that informative session last week.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lastly, on reports, is the report on state fiscal year 2018 budget challenges.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is the motion to accept the report and place it on file?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The numbers should start to circulate out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're expecting the cherry shoots, possibly midweek, and that kind of spells out the governor's idea of what we'll be getting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then we wait for the house ways and means, really, is what we use for the budget to set our budget numbers.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they'll all be coming in stride.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is the motion to receive in place on file by Mr. Skerry, seconded by Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The motion carries.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We do have...

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And lastly, as you may be aware, this is public school week.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have a proclamation we'd like to circulate to the members of the school committee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I could read it really quickly if you so choose.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas all children in the City of Medford should have access to the highest quality education possible.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the City of Medford recognizes the important role that an effective education plays in preparing all students in Medford to be successful adults.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas quality education is critically important to the economic vitality of the City of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the City of Medford is home to quality public schools for our children.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas public education not only helps to diversify our economy but also enhances the vibrancy of our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas the City of Medford has many high-quality teaching professionals who are committed to educating our children, and whereas public schools are celebrated across the country by millions of students, parents, educators, schools, and organizations to raise awareness of the need for effective public schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now, therefore, we, the Medford School Committee, Medford, Massachusetts, do hereby recognize January 22nd to the 28th, 2017, as the City of Medford Public Schools Week and call this observance to the attention of all our citizens.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to adjourn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the White Ribbon Day pledge states, from this day forward, I promise to be a part of the solution in ending violence against women and all gender-based violence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good evening, elected officials, clergy, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Clayton, you who sung so beautifully, city and school employees, and fellow Medford residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so very much for being here, and thank you to all of those watching from home.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To the youth of our community who just recited the proclamation, you inspire us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You have been raised in a time of tolerance and compassion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You embrace the diversity of our city and our country.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Remain vigilant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These are trying times for our nation, no matter our personal views.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But as Tip O'Neill always said, all politics is local.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're together this evening as one city because we are strong and believe in writing this chapter together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The current state of the city of Medford is summed up in three words, sound, stable, and sturdy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as-

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As your mayor, I stand ready to work with you to chart a new course into an even greater tomorrow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It seems like the inauguration was just yesterday when we, as a community, collectively said, it all starts today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, since that day, much time has been spent among our residents,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: business owners, and staff working in collaboration with one another and elected officials on all levels of government to have a high-level dialogue to renew and improve our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I am very proud of the work done thus far, because it continues today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'd like to start with a focus on our finances, because a sound financial foundation is the catalyst for continuing our progress.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The city's unemployment rate on 12-31 was 2.3 percent, compared to Boston's 2.5.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford dropped from 3.7 percent this past June.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our bond rating is AA from Standard & Poor's and AA3 from Moody's, high-quality ratings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Average single families' homes are assessed at 476,000, and Medford has a stable housing market.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We closed out fiscal 16 with free cash of $9.7 million.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is our city's rainy day fund.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And since last February, Treasurer Irwin has aggressively pursued tax title cases, having collected $1.9 million, thus far compared with

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Compared with 900,000 the previous year, the treasurer and assessor are implementing the Community Preservation Act, CPA, which was passed by the Medford voters this past November of 15 and went into effect on July 1st of 16.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We project fiscal 17 collections to estimate $1.2 million, which will be available for use beginning in July.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Its purpose is for affordable housing, open space, and historic preservation initiatives.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are accepting applications until February 12th for the four at-large appointments to the Community Preservation Commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have reinvented the senior work-off abatement program, allowing 35 seniors to earn up to $1,500 in abatements during this current fiscal year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This successful program

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This successful program was a win for us seniors, it was a win for City Hall, and it was a win for the residents as a whole.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so, so much for your dedication to the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Ruth and Vivian.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The roles included assisting in early voting, which we got 20,000 people to early vote this year, greeting people at city hall, handling the mail and other tasks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're looking to open up the program again to new seniors starting April 1st.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In addition to this abatement, the city offers many statutory exemptions for seniors and veterans.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I will also be forwarding a request to the city council to raise the exemption levels by 50% for veterans and seniors in the coming months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are also working with the State Division of Local Services to review the owner-occupied exemption calculation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We know there's a fundamental flaw in it, and we're going to work with our partners at the state to try and correct it, at least for Medford, if not for the whole Commonwealth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the focus on finances continues today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In March, our community signed on to the Governor's Community Compact, which is a commitment to best practices.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Through this compact, we are pursuing two major initiatives that directly impact the quality of life in our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The first is Complete Streets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Complete Streets changes the thought process when performing road projects.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It provides equal weight to all modes of transportation, whether it be walking, biking, wheelchairs, transit, as well as motor vehicles.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We were awarded a $400,000 grant from the state to implement this strategy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This funding will allow us to focus on six projects that will provide the reconfiguration of intersections, pedestrian signals, bike lanes, signage, and crosswalk enhancements.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The Complete Streets team, led by our engineer, Cassandra Koudelidis,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We'll be holding forums the next two Wednesday nights to review the plan so the construction can begin in the spring.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One such project is a major reconfiguration of Tufts Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The second compact item is the Medford Square revitalization plan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have received $90,000 from the State Technical Assistance Grant and the Barr Foundation Grant to facilitate the planning process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Director Lauren DiLorenzo has spearheaded public meetings, which provided great input and feedback.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In March, we will be ready to move forward and ensure that this planning comes to fruition.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In coordination with this process, I am very, very proud to make an announcement tonight that the Rudra Hospitality Group has closed on the property at 101 George B. Hassett Drive, just next door to us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They will be applying to construct a 124-room Premier Brand hotel with a sky bar and a 350-seat rooftop function room.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This $25 to $30 million investment will create 200 construction jobs, an estimate 50 permanent jobs, and projected tax revenues just at construction cost, not value, Mr. Assessor, is $600,000 per year to start.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I want to thank the team that includes John Veneziano of ERA Andrew, Realtors, and the Rudra Group for working with us to be the first domino to fall in the revitalization of Medford Square and trusting in this city's vision and process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much to the group, John and the Rudra.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know you're here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The end.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The city was also awarded a land and water grant of $250,000 that will match city money to reimagine the Riverside Plaza adjacent to the burial grounds in Medford Square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We envision this multi-purpose space to act as a common of sorts for our community events.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As Vince Lombardi said, individual commitment to a group effort, that is what makes a team work, a company work, a society work, a civilization work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is this commitment by my transition teams, citizens, city employees, and elected officials on all levels of government that has fostered this cooperative effort.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Economic development and development in general is necessary to maintain a financially strong municipality.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Prop two and a half without new growth barely covers contractual obligations, let alone health and pension costs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We rely on new growth to be able to augment services, such as offering a year-round recreation program that is being recommended by our focus group, which Councilor Scott Peli is spearheading with a group of committed residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, George.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With the housing shortage forecast from the state, we must continue to invite varied housing opportunities in our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I applaud Councilman Knight, Chair of the Zoning Subcommittee, for work toward revising some outdated zoning ordinances on our books.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To assist in this process, we have applied for a technical assistant grant with the Metropolitan Area Planning Council, specifically for the Mystic Avenue Corridor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Adam.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So economic development continues today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And while we stress economic development, we cannot forget the richness that the creative economy brings to our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The Chevalier Theater is the gem of our community and adds tremendous value from cultural events, musical performances, and much, much more.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And while the first request for proposal, or RFP in our world, for management of the theater was deemed non-responsive, we have formed a new evaluation team.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is comprised of three members of the commission and three members from City Hall to craft a new RFP, which is nearly complete.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We learned a great deal from the first round, and we will use this to select a partner that will invest in the infrastructure of this historic gem while managing it with a focus on partnerships with local businesses and organizations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Speaking of organizations, as a community, we are so very blessed to have entities such as Medford Arts Council, Cachet, Mystic Makerspace, Mackey, the Farmer's Market, Chamber of Commerce, Brooks Estate Land Trust, and the Human Rights Commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You enrich our being every day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I...

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I thank you for the selfless work you do each and every day to embrace and promote our creative, historic, and cultural perspectives.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We also want to thank those that served on the library building committee led by Barbara Kerr, our library director, and our president, Rick Caraviello.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Proud to say we have submitted the grant to the state for library funding, quite an accomplishment in such a short amount of time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also, I ask you, how do we make you aware of all the things we're doing?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: First, we have created linguistic capability to have ConnectCTY, better known as hashtag Barry called, to reach out to the community via phone, text, and email in 11 different languages.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Diane McLeod, for spearheading that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are on Facebook.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Twitter, and of course, the web.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Second, public access will be back on the airwaves by late spring.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The studio is being constructed at the front of Medford High School, where we will get a double bang for our buck.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The students will learn media tech during the day, while the public will have access during the evenings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Who better to tell the stories of Medford than you, the citizens of Medford?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Mayor Mike McGlynn, for leading this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Bringing arts and culture to the forefront continues today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This winter, I signed on to the Metro Mayors Mitigation Compact to become carbon neutral region-wide by 2050.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This raises

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This raises environmental consciousness with every decision the City makes going forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To this end, we initiated the process last fall to purchase the streetlights that are owned and managed by National Grid, with the goal to convert to LED over the summer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We anticipate savings in electricity usage, thus reducing environmental emittances.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And based on direct maintenance by us of the lights, there will be a less than 5-year payback from converting to LED.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In addition,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In collaboration with the City Council, we are experimenting with increased lighting in Medford Square for our decorative lights.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Once finalized, we will fully install for a safer streetscape in our square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our Office of Environment has been hard at work to receive the following grants for additional projects.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: $250,000 grant from the Stanton Foundation to build a dog park at Riverbend Park, which will be built this spring.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And thank you, PAWS4.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A grant from the Mass Coastal Zone Management for $125,000 to build the city's first green infrastructure to naturally clean stormwater before it flows into the Mystic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is a partnership with the Mystic River Watershed Association, or MIRA as we refer to it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: a partnership grant for the Clippership Connector from DCR to design and engineer the half-mile multi-use path between Medford Square and Riverbend Park.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is in partnership with Block Medford and Myra and a generous donation from Wegmans for $23,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Wegmans.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're not even in our city and they're already contributing to these wonderful things.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very lucky to have them coming and they expect construction to end by next October, November timeframe.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We received a green community grant, another green community grant for 250,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's for LED lighting in our schools, which will be installed over the next few weeks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These grants would not be possible without the hard work of the team in the energy and environment under the leadership of Alicia Hunt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Alicia recently received the Mystic Municipal Leadership Award from the Mystic River Watershed Association.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much, Alicia, for all your hard work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I also want to thank Eagle Scout candidate Calvin Lambert.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I believe he's in the audience.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Calvin.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's working with our environmental office and our Department of Public Works to build bridges around Wright's Pond for sensitive areas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much, Calvin, for your efforts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lastly, we have created the Go Green Medford Coalition, which will be an umbrella entity for all sustainability-minded groups in Medford to coordinate activities and track outcomes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Environmental focus continues today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As chairperson of the Medford School Committee, working with committee members, administration, and faculty, our public schools continue to make great achievements.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Examples include.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: increased access to career and technical education for Medford students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The integration of Medford High and Medford Voc Tech has enabled our students to simultaneously participate in both rigorous academics and occupational exploration skill development.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nine new Chapter 74 technical programs are now available.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Heidi, Riccio, and the superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Enrollment of ninth grade students in career tech education has doubled under her leadership.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've also secured over $1 million in new grants to revitalize our vocational technical learning environment, and we've also captured out-of-district tuitions and generated new sources of regionalized revenue to support expansion of educational opportunities for our youth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have maintained a comprehensive curriculum that provides a full range of core academic subjects and specialized electives.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford offers 16 advanced placement courses, among the most in the area, as well as a full complement of art, music, technology, foreign language, and health education programs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and members of the school committee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have two standout Medford students with us tonight, Joseph Farah and Ketty Toussaint.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Joseph, a Medford High School senior, took first place at the Massachusetts State Science and Engineering Fair in developing scientific models, while Ketty graduated last spring from Medford Tech and is currently enrolled at Massachusetts College of Pharmacy and Health Services.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As an immigrant from Haiti, she left her homeland at the age of 11 with her dad.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She worked hard to learn the English language and excelled in her technical program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ketty also earned college credit through a dual enrollment program at Bunker Hill Community College.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Both of these young adults demonstrate the Medford Public Schools advantage, MPS advantage, in our commitment to you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have introduced before school programs at our elementary schools, while after school programs are growing exponentially.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They provide substantial coverage and constructive activities for students after regular hours.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are enhancing our programs and activities to provide inclusive opportunities for all students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In order to accomplish this, substantial professional development with an emphasis on social and emotional learning in our schools has been made.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have added counseling and behavior support staff to our teams.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lastly, we're recognized by the National School Board's Journal for School Security Practices.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have tightened security at all schools by adding staff and the Raptor ID system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Investments in our school children continue today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Augmented security measures at our schools would not be possible without collaboration with our public safety professionals.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Safety is a core component to an individual's comfort in and desire to be in a community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have invested in state-of-the-art self-contained breathing apparatus for our firefighters and a second set of turnout gear.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Medford City Council for voting that last night, for supporting this initiative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These are to provide the most current apparatus for firefighters' safety and ultimately for your safety.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nine new firefighters graduated the academy last month and one entered this past Monday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are working hard to keep up with retirements by accelerating the civil service process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kudos to our Board of Health for receipt of a seven-year, $100,000 per year grant from the Mass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Department of Public Health Bureau of Substance Abuse to provide opiate abuse prevention services for six cities and towns in our area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We all understand the impact this drug has on our society, and we are making every effort to raise awareness, erase the stigma, and provide assistance for those suffering from addiction, as well as support for their families.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have formed a team approach under Mary Ann O'Connor, who recently came to us in the last several months, for our prevention and outreach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have an outreach manager, a recovery coach.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We work with Lawrence Memorial Hospital and the Police Department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Every life matters, and we thank our police and firefighters for volunteering to administer Narcan in this cause.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And while we are not declared a trust act city, be assured that our police department protocols do not allow for profiling.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Witnesses and victims are not asked about their immigration status.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So be sure, and that's the way it is.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you would ask me what the question posed to me most often,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I would have to say it's when are we getting a new police station?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I hear it day in and day out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And today, just this morning, I announced that we will be submitting a loan order to the city council next week on February 14th, requesting funds to commission an architect to begin the plans for a new station.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have turned this city upside down looking for a new location.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've toured commercial spaces.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've contacted property owners.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Property owners have contacted us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And in the end, the right location, with no land costs and no relocation during construction, is the current site of the training facility on Main Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The current facility will be demolished, and the proposed 35,000-square-foot, three-story new construction will house all amenities of the state-of-the-art resilient headquarters, including deserved equal space for our female and male officers, technology upgrades, and, most importantly, safe interior space for our offices' well-being.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Public safety investments continue today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In conclusion, this city of ours, this great city of ours, continues to move forward on a foundation built on dialogue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue that echoes in this building, allowing the voices of all residents to be heard with an attitude of inclusion and fairness.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue of renewal, where creative and imaginative ideas are brought forward to better the quality of life in our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A dialogue that resonates with the message that Medford is on the move, embracing a future of possibilities, embracing a future of hope.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On this night, in our beautiful city hall, and I say that the state of our city is sound, it is stable, and it is sturdy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as your mayor, I stand as committed as ever to foster this dialogue with you as we continue to cultivate a city on which we can be partners in progress.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: God bless Medford, the Commonwealth, and the United States of America.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you all very much for being here this evening, and good night, and be safe tomorrow with the upcoming blizzard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you all very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The regular meeting of the Medford School Committee will now come to order.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Please call the roll, Madam Secretary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Trotta.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Item eight report on technology infrastructure study for capital planning and E-rate fund acquisition.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have been working with this organization.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Update report on new public records law and appointment of MPS, public records access officer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could, prior to the superintendent speaking, there was a change in the law this past year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was set to implement 2017, which is why this is before you today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I just wanted to go on record that we are required to have a records access officer named for the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And because of the size of our community, we felt it was wise to have a city person as well as a school person that's responsible for all the freedom of information requests that come through our doors on a daily basis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have named Kim Scanlon, who's Assistant City Solicitor, as the RAO for the City of Medford, and the Superintendent would like to announce his selection.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They will be the gatekeeper, though, to make sure when requests that come in, answers go out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it'll organize the process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Right now, you could send it to any department head, and they're doing their own freedom of information request.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to approve.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We wish everyone a wonderful holiday season.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Stay safe out there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have some bad weather coming, some ice cold weather coming, so stay warm, stay bundled.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to adjourn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you everybody for being here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roy has pretty much introduced everyone in the entire city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I wanted just a heartfelt thanks to everyone who has committed so much time and energy to this project.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We know it wasn't easy so it took a lot of effort on behalf of the city and the school to pull this together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know that in some communities they do have the public access and mixed in integrated with their school system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we think that that's a great idea.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's very beneficial for not only our students, but our entire population of the city of Bedford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really thrilled to be embarking on this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a full circle.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We started out this way, if I'm not mistaken, Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then we took it and we had our public access separate from our school programming.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so much of it is overlapped and integrated.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very excited to be bringing it back to the high school in a fully handicapped accessible area that you will see shortly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also just to have the voice of Medford to be heard again on the airwaves.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think we're just very, very excited about that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've been silent for several years now when our public access channel closed down.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're just really eager to get it up and running again because it's so important to tell the stories through the eyes of the people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: not the professionals.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very, very excited about that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I look forward to this groundbreaking and ribbon cutting all in one.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we do just want to mention that Integrated Construction Corp of Medford actually received the award for this contract.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was $756,000 for the work to be done.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A whole host of equipment we're purchasing separately that we'll be pulling into this programming.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're probably going to be up over a million dollars when all is said and done.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it's a lot of money, but it's a community, school, city benefit.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we think it's money well spent and we hope that these students have the opportunity to explore the station in the spring.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and that they bring their voice to the airwaves.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very excited about the opportunities that you will gain from this and the public in general.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much for being here today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I really appreciate you all taking the time out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: of the state legislation that would have to be adopted by the city, the school committee, in order to move this into place.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if I could read the state chapter, general law chapter 71, section 55D, small a, upon the issuance of a musical wind instrument to a student who is permitted to use or borrow the instrument while attending any public or commonwealth charter school or pre-kindergarten to grade 12, inclusive,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The school issuing the instrument shall inform the student's parent or guardian that the musical wind instrument has been sanitized and may also be sterilized at the expense of the parent or guardian requesting sterilization to ensure that all microbial life has been eradicated from the instrument.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The parent or guardian may request that the school sterilize the instrument prior to issuance in compliance with regulations promulgated by the Department of Public Health.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The parent or guardian who makes the request shall be responsible for the entire cost of the sterilization.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Small b, this section shall take effect in any city, town, or regional school district upon acceptance by the school committee, or in the case of a commonwealth charter school, upon acceptance by the board of trustees, respectfully submitted by myself, Mayor Stephanie M. Burke.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We also have Solicitor Rumley here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I don't know if he wanted to say a few words on this topic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion for approval by Mr. Skerry, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Vierne de Kloet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Would you like to comment now?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Did you want to wait for an answer?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So, um,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's exactly correct.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Interpretation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All set?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion on the floor for approval by Mr. Skerry, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot, Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is informational to the parents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Notification to the parents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's what this general law is.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Providing notification to the parents, and then it's up to them to take action.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If they so please, they may look up research and disagree with the findings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's totally at the parents' wishes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I agree, Mr. Bellson.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to move the question.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Report of the secretary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Are there any?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: None.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is none.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Report of committees.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: None.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're actually waiting for one individual to come, and as soon as he arrives, I would love you to make that motion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Oh, he's actually in the back of the room.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion for suspension of the rules to take the resolution under new business.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Resolution submitted by Mayor Stephanie M. Burke.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The Medford School Committee support the Medford Conversations Project to promote dialogue and collaboration about race and ethnicity in Medford and beyond.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And there's actually a full resolution that's in your packet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was presented to the City Council last Tuesday evening and it passed seven to zero.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if I could read the resolution.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas the strength of our nation is derived from its history of diversity that has enriched our communities with a variety of cultures, faiths, traditions, and viewpoints.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the City of Medford is a community that welcomes and values the varied racial and ethnic makeup of our residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the City of Medford stands in support of all immigrant groups and newcomers as they pursue the American dream.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the City of Medford will work to model our city as a safe and welcoming place that equally encourages all to seek personal advancement and to reside in peaceful contentment in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas the City of Medford rejects all words and acts of hate, indifference, and intolerance that undermine our neighborhoods, communities of faith, and our schools, and thwart the promise of equal justice.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas our nation was founded on the fundamental principle that all persons are entitled to equal protection of law, equal opportunity, and to the enjoyment of civil and human rights.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now, therefore, the City of Medford proudly supports the Medford Conversations Project to promote dialogue and collaboration about race and ethnicity in Medford and beyond.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I believe we have Mr. D. O'Brien in the audience, and Reverend Wendy, would you like to speak on this resolution?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Reverend Wendy, your name and address for the record, please?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much, Reverend Wendy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there anyone else that would like to speak on this resolution before us this evening?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good evening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You name and address, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much, Mr. Schnepp.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Stone.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: medfordconversations.org.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much for being here tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is a motion on the floor for acceptance of the resolution by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a second?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Seconded by Mr. Skerry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's to provide a unified voice that we will not accept acts of hatred and inequality.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's not who we are, that's not who we want to be, and that we all speak united on that topic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We see that a lot, but there are a lot that don't.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And to those out there, we're making a statement that it's important that we acknowledge that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is our way of making a public statement that that is who we are.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Vanderpool.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also, the superintendent and I are working on a PSA, trying to get the community involved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we'll probably be reaching out to Steve.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think I sat at your table several months ago, and he did a great job facilitating that meeting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we'll be working probably with some in your group to try and put a PSA out that addresses some of these issues in a conversational forum of four people, maybe.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we will be in touch with you in the very near future for that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On the motion of approval by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot, seconded by Mr. Skerry, roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, six in the affirmative, none in the negative, one absent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The resolution passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, absolutely.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Come forward, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: How are you?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good, thanks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You can stand tall.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much for coming tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm sure mom's proud.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're passing along a signature sheet, if you could sign it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It will be posted in City Hall, and we'll send a copy up to the school department as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Community participation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I see none.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if you could send that letter in on our behalf, we appreciate it, Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And there's just a couple of items the superintendent would like to mention.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion to adjourn?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to adjourn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: the state legislation that would have to be adopted by the city, the school committee, in order to move this into place.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if I could read the state chapter, general law chapter 71, section 55D, small a, upon the issuance of a musical wind instrument to a student who is permitted to use or borrow the instrument while attending any public or commonwealth charter school or pre-kindergarten to grade 12, inclusive,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The school issuing the instrument shall inform the student's parent or guardian that the musical wind instrument has been sanitized and may also be sterilized at the expense of the parent or guardian requesting sterilization to ensure that all microbial life has been eradicated from the instrument.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The parent or guardian may request that the school sterilize the instrument prior to issuance in compliance with regulations promulgated by the Department of Public Health.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The parent or guardian who makes the request shall be responsible for the entire cost of the sterilization.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Small b, this section shall take effect in any city, town, or regional school district upon acceptance by the school committee, or in the case of a Commonwealth charter school, upon acceptance by the Board of Trustees, respectfully submitted by myself, Mayor Stephanie M. Burke.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the City of Medford is a community that welcomes and values the varied racial and ethnic makeup of our residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the City of Medford stands in support of all immigrant groups and newcomers as they pursue the American dream.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the City of Medford will work to model our city as a safe and welcoming place that equally encourages all to seek personal advancement and to reside in peaceful contentment in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am going to spend it with my sister and my whole family.
