[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I graduated with this guy and his wife Sue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So even though we're not on the Malden line, we're really in Medford, the heart of Medford here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I want to wish you all a great Thanksgiving Day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good luck out on the field.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: we'd want to bring the trophy home, but you know, it's more to be good sportsmen on that day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's all about that and camaraderie.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You look around the room, you see what Malden and Metro have made of, and we're a great two cities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've got a great history, second oldest rivalry, contiguous rivalry going on here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So keep it going, represent your cities well, and I look forward to seeing y'all more in the very near future, probably tomorrow at the Metropolitan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We'll be out there at the

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: big event, the big event tomorrow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So go get them, have fun, and enjoy your Thanksgiving holidays.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We also have our superintendent, Roy Bilson.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good evening, Mr. President and Councilors.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much for taking me out of order.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I really appreciate it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As many of you are aware, last Friday the FAA had a meeting on the noise, the noise issues that we've been having in the city from the low flying planes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Councilor Lungo-Koehn was in attendance as well as Councilor Capiello and Mark Rumley, the city solicitor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We all kind of went up, hoping that we would get in, and at the last minute we found out that we did not have clearance to enter the FAA building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We stayed for quite a while, and finally, when Congresswoman Clark appeared, she was able to overrule their rules, which required a 48-hour notice to have someone on the list.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I was able to attend and sit in on the meeting, which we know impacts several of the neighborhoods throughout Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This meeting was put together at the bequest of a state senator that represented the Belmont Watertown area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the FAA was just listening to the request, and that's why they held the meeting, and it was scheduled with those parties involved, and the city of Medford really wasn't invited formally.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I did want to just come back to let you know what transpired during the meeting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Obviously, a lot of the CAC members, Logan has a community board as well as Massport, so the two separate community boards that meet regularly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And several of those members were in attendance during this meeting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They had been previously cleared.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they brought the issues of what they're dealing with as well as we are.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We all know firsthand that there's certain sections of the city that have been impacted by the change and basically what the FAA has tried to do is simplify the air

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: travel routes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So back a year or so ago, a year and a half, the planes were dispersed over multiple cities throughout the Commonwealth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So when they took off, they were dispersed, so we all dealt with an occasional sound here and there, but nobody was impacted

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: directly all day long with a certain sound.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They try to simplify the skies, make travel lanes, and therefore it has brought about the volume that is going over one particular route in the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's actually quite an area over the Malden Hospital.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's where the planes that come off of runway 33L, they actually split, and they go in different directions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that particular area gets hit very hard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And in a lot of the studies that the community groups have done,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're actually looking at the Stearns Ave area as being hit very, very hard in our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So what we talked to the FAA about was, what are you going to do about it?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're all dealing with this issue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a quality of life issue in our neighborhood and the surrounding communities, and what are you going to do?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they basically told us that they have MIT, Massport has commissioned MIT to do a formal study, but it will not be ready until next fall.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So a year from now, they'll get the results of the sound

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: testing that they have commissioned through Massport.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And of course, we all said that's not good enough.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Go back to the way it was.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Do something different.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the FAA's position is that it's all about safety.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Their main concern above and beyond sound is safety for

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: the flights, the people on the planes, the pilots, and the workers, and the FAA in general.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they heard our cry for help, and not only is it that there are the numbers that are traveling down these roads in the sky, but the elevation, the volume,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: which are two of the main concerns that are also causing havoc in our area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they listened intently.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They said that they were going to reach out through Massport and try to get some more information quicker.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We actually do have a sound study that's part of Massport that's set up in Magoon Thatcher area and that they do not have the results from that yet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So once they get those results, they will be forthcoming to us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They use a 65 decibel as their magic number, and that's what they've been using as their level that is tolerable.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so I know what I mentioned to them is that they need to stop looking at things from the sky, and they need to come down to the neighborhoods and see the real impact that it's causing on our citizens.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they did seem to listen, they're heavily on, they want to do constituent service, community involvement, so they vowed to us that they will be having many more community meetings and we're actually going to be working with Senator Markey's office to get a straight Medford meeting, which all of you certainly will be able to attend.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we are working on putting that together in the next couple of weeks so that we can deal with the Medford issues in particular.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And just lastly, I just wanted to mention that today I've named Peter Hook to the Massport CAC community group, and Luke Priessner as the Logan CAC representative, and the backup to Logan will be Peter.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: who's on our mass board.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So these two individuals have been very much involved in this process the entire time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They've been outspoken and data-driven and looked at a lot of the facts and circumstances around the area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I know that they will hit the ground running.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They will be invested and involved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It directly impacts their quality of life.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm looking forward to them serving on behalf of the city of Medford, and I'm sure that they will do a great job.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I just wanted to give you a verbal update on the Friday meeting, um, so that you're all aware of it as well as the general public.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we can move forward and try to rectify the issues that are at hand.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It didn't sound like from the FAA that they were taking any actions immediate, because they're waiting on this MIT study to determine everything.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They said, basically, they can't just look at our runway in particular, because our runway impacts every other runway.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if they ought to alter the routes in our area,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's like a domino effect, it impacts every other route that affects Milton, the North Shore, the South Shore.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it didn't sound like they will be taking action, but I believe that that's a Massport meeting, so these gentlemen will be in attendance.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: FAA controls the sky lanes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Massport controls the time that the planes can run,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: how many can go up, how frequent that they can be dispersed out of Logan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's funny when you bring up certain issues to FAA, they say, well, that's not really it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We just tell them where they can go.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We don't tell them when they can go and how many can go, the frequency.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But certainly, if they're all going and they're all going down a certain route, we're impacted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they heard us loud and clear.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I would doubt very much that they're going to do anything that's going to impact a particular area, especially until the study's done.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Enjoy your family and enjoy your meal.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We did have a Massport representative that attended some of the meetings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Unfortunately, they've canceled several of the last few months based upon not having enough information.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we did have a representative that was at those meetings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The original Logan CAC was established many, many years ago, and it was for sound, really, looking at the sound lanes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then the Massport CAC kicked in that looks at everything, all the operations of Massport.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we do have a Massport CAC.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you're aware, I just named some new bodies to that so that we will have full activity on that commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It has an appointment and it has a...

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: an alternate as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I can't go back prior to the year, the 10 months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I can only look at the 10 months and I wasn't aware that Logan, I don't even know if Logan has had a meeting, but Massport has had meetings over the last several months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Massport has had several meetings as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, I've actually read the Mass Support and the Logan, their enabling legislation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they're supposed to be in attendance, and if they miss a few, I think it's three meetings in one case, they're different between the two.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're supposed to notify the appointing authority that someone is not going to these meetings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if they're not, if they were not notifying, obviously they didn't notify me, or I would have taken action.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: before tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So going forward, we're going to check.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We'll get a monthly report from the meetings themselves.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These individuals are very active in the community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're very active with this particular issue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I know that they will make us very proud and we'll be reflecting our interests there as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Councilor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Peter Hoek from Massport CAC.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Luke Prisner for Logan CAC.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Peter will be the alternate on the Logan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Happy Thanksgiving.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Report on Medford Public Schools disciplinary statistics.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to receive and place this report on file.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Aye.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion carries.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Report on school system guidance on national election results.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And even Thursday when we attended the veteran ceremony that was spoken about earlier this evening, it was made clear that to stay away from this topic, the students and the teachers have all been kind of addressed through this email, and that let's just deal with the Veterans Day topic at hand and not delve into the high emotions that have been running.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I think one of your lines in here really sums it up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is no room for hate messaging.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think that message is loud and clear from not only the superintendent, but the city, school committee members, et cetera.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we just really need to strive to raise it up, raise the level of conversation up, and treat all people equally.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On the motion to receive and place on file this report, all those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Aye.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion carries.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Old Business is an update on the crossing guard issue that was raised at the last meeting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It had to do with the Felsway location, in particular,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Two locations on the Felsway actually, one at the base of Fels Ave and one at the base of Fulton Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know that the superintendent has been in touch with Mr. Representative Donato.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also I spoke with Commissioner Roy of the DCR and he said that he had the engineers go out and they do not see any issues with extending the time limit on the push button.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They said that that was too, people complained that it was too short to get across the entire Felsway, which is quite a wide road.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So he said that that will be addressed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was going to call me back to give me an exact date.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I asked him about the crossing guards, and he said that they're really trying to get out of the crossing guard business.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I did mention that there could be a couple of locations that may be lower visibility, that if possible, if he could relocate a crossing guard that's currently in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: maybe to this location, and then we could potentially change the bus route to address the fewer children that are affected in a different location.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was going to go back to the drawing boards and talk to his people to see if that's a possibility.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I know Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kreatz, you have an update as well?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yeah.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I think the added time will be sufficient to get across the entire cycle because right now it's what, 12?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, we are in the crossing guard business and we would have to do an MOU, memorandum of understanding, in order to take over their location.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: or their street in particular.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we will have to review that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so that takes place at the American Legion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So please make sure you come on down.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're trying to increase participation each of the nights during the Jingle Bell Festival.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so hopefully you'll have a chance to come on down.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They said that that was too, people complained that it was too short to get across the entire Felsway, which is quite a wide road.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: S han sagde att det kommer att uppst.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Han ville kalla mig tillbaka fr att ge mig en exakt datum.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Jag frade honom om crossingsgrden, och han sa att de verkligen frsker att sls av crossingsgrden.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Och jag menade att det kan finnas ngra stllen som har mindre visibilitet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: S om det r mjligt, om han kan placerar en crossingsgrd som r i Medford, kanske p den hr platsen, och d kan vi kanske frndra vgen till busen fr att uppst de mindre barn som r affektade p olika stllen.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was going to go back to the drawing boards and talk to his people to see if that's a possibility.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I don't know, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So please come down, support the local charities that this great initiative goes toward, in particular the Buddy Cohalan Center for Alzheimer's.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So please make sure you come on down.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also we want to wish everyone a very happy, peaceful Thanksgiving this Thursday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then Thursday night there will be a vigil from the Grace Church to City Hall for overcoming addiction.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Friday night, the scouts, girls and boys, will be down having an event here as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're trying to increase participation each of the nights during the Jingle Bell Festival.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so hopefully you'll have a chance to come on down.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'm sure it will look much different next time you see it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the last item on the agenda, negotiations and legal matters.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion to go into executive session?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mae'r ymdrechion presidenol y byddai'r myfyrwyr yng Nghymru wedi'u cyflawni, ond mae'n ddiddorol ar y cwestiynau.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Dw i ddim yn edrych ar yr ymdrechion presidenol, ond roedd y cwestiynau un yn dweud nid.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: 137 y cyhoeddiad i 66.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cwestiynau ddau, roedd y nod wedi'i wneud, 169-37.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cwestiynau ddau, roedd y nod wedi'i wneud, 78-24.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cwestiynau ddau, roedd y nod wedi'i wneud, 150-70.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Felly, ganlyniadau ddiddorol iawn, ac rydyn ni'n gweld sut maen nhw'n chwarae ymlaen y diwrnod hwnnw.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nid unig'r broblemau, ond y persona o'r candidatau.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: ac mae'n ddweud eich bod ni'n ymgyrchu'n genedlaethol y byddaf i'w gysylltu ar y cyfrifiad cyntaf hefyd, felly hwyl i'r myfyrwyr ar hyn o bryd.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Gwych fideo, ac, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kreatz, rydych chi'n blincio.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roeddwn i am ddweud y byddai'n gwaith gwych ym mhrifysgolion, ac roedd hi'n ddiddorol iawn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Dwi'n teimlo y byddai rhywun yno yn dod allan a dweud, dyma gwahanol penderfynas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yn ymwneud ag Ysgrifennydd Van der Klooth, yn ymwneud ag Mr

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Vandekloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The first one has to do with the foundation budget which is used to calculate all the local aid that we get from for the school department from the state.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's be it resolved that MASC calls upon the legislature to enact the recommendations of the foundation budget into law and further that the legislature order the Commission to reconvene in order to conduct further deliberations and

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and make such recommendations as the FBRC may propose, and further, that the FBRC shall address and make recommendations toward the overall accuracy of the adequacy of the overall foundation budget.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Point of information, Mr. Scarey.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have not.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have not had any 9C cuts inflicted upon us yet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Uh-huh.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It did.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think back in 2009, we had nine seat cuts, which are really hard to do when you get notice in December and January, because you're basically cutting a year's worth of a cut in six months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're following quite closely.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion for approval of this first resolution?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Meeting that it meets all communities on the motion as amended on resolution one motion seconded roll call vote.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, 7 in the affirmative, 0 in the negative on the motion as amended.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Resolution 2, tax reform ballot question.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Talks about greater tax equity that will not raise taxes on any but the wealthiest residents of Massachusetts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Massachusetts Association of School Committees explore ways to promote social and economic equity through a valid initiative whose purpose may include a state constitutional amendment, tax reform, protection of the state's neediest residents of all ages, and seeks additional revenue only from tax reform affecting the state's wealthiest residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Further, that the goal of such a ballot referendum will be to secure a stronger financial base to underwrite needed improvements in the infrastructure of the Commonwealth, as well as the educational, social, and economic well-being of its residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion on the floor for approval of this resolution number two?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion for approval.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Skerry, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: DeAnderklut.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Scarry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, seven to zero, seven in favor, motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Resolution three, charter school reform.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Oh, this is a long one.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm going to go right down to the be it resolved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Therefore, be it resolved that the Massachusetts Association of School Committees urge the citizens of the Commonwealth to reject such a ballot initiative and further, that MASC seeks legislative approval of a comprehensive set of reforms that include, one,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Establishment of strict guidelines or regulations to require the charter schools enrolled represent cross-sections of students residing within the school service areas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Two, reporting of accurate number of students who leave charter schools to return to the sending district or district of residence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Three, requiring, well I'm sorry, requiring the Mass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to retain and report accurate data on enrollment of students with learning disabilities, physical disabilities, economic disadvantage, emotional disability, and status as racial and linguistic minorities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Four, state requirements that any charter school authorized in a community without its consent be funded in full by the Commonwealth rather than by expropriation of Chapter 70 education aid from ascending cities, towns, and regions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Five, state funding in full of any mitigation funds created to offset the loss of state funding for students who become students in charter schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So noted that Mr. Benedetto will abstain based upon her working for a charter school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is the motion for approval by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Vanden Heuvel, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: over $4 million.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's on our cherry sheets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you can look up the state aid.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you can see the revenue that comes from the state expenses.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They charge us such as tea.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They hit us for being a tea community, which is quite a couple million dollars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Charter schools is another big hit that we have.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So please, go up and look.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's enlightening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yeah, I think the thing about the charter schools is we're not, like you said, we're not saying they're not great educational facilities, but when you pluck one first grader out of the school, maybe one first out of another school, we don't lose a whole classroom.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we don't gain any efficiencies.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We just, we lose one here and there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the next thing you know, we're up to what number, Mr. Billson?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: you know, all the different grades and schools and classrooms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're not able to just cut classrooms, you know, without putting on numbers up to the 25, 26 average.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Resolution proposed by Mayor Burke, proclamation by Mayor Burke, supporting and celebrating keeping lights on, keeping lights on after school of proclamation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Can I read this whole motion?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas the citizens of Medford stand firmly committed to quality after school programs and opportunities because they provide challenging and engaging learning experiences that help

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Children develop social, emotional, physical and academic skills while supporting working families, ensuring their children are safe and productive after the traditional school day ends.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas the City of Medford has provided significant leadership in the area of community involvement in the education and well-being of our youth, grounded in the principle that quality after-school programs are key to helping our children become successful adults.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas Lights On After School, the national celebration of after-school programs held this year on October 22, 2016, promotes the importance of quality after-school programs in the lives of children, families, and communities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas more than 28 million children in the U.S.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: have parents who work outside the home, and 15.1 million children have no place to go after school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas many after-school programs across the country are facing funding shortfalls so severe that they are being forced to close their doors and turn off their lights.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas the City of Medford is committed to investing in the health and safety of all young people by providing after-school and out-of-school time programs that will help close the achievement gap and prepare young people to compete in the global economy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas it is important to engage families, schools, and communities in advancing the welfare of our children and ensure the lights stay on and the doors stay open for all children after school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now the FRI, Stephanie Burke, Mayor of the City of Medford, do hereby proclaim October 22, 2016 to be Lights On After School Day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and urge all the citizens of Medford to take cognizance of this event and participate fittingly in its observance, given this 17th day of October in the year 2016, and of the independence of the United States of America, the 240.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion for approval.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion for approval, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: School Committee Resolution.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was the husband of Marlene English, former Medford Public School Secretary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mustone?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There are four resolutions in our packet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They are quite lengthy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion to read the entire resolution?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Vandekloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The first one has to do with the foundation budget which is used to calculate all of the local aid that we get for the school department from the state.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's be it resolved that MASC calls upon the legislature to enact the recommendations of the foundation budget into law and further that the legislature order the commission to reconvene in order to conduct further deliberations and make such recommendations as the FBRC may propose and further

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: that the FBRC shall address and make recommendations toward the overall accuracy of the adequacy of the overall foundation budget.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have not had any 9C cuts inflicted upon us yet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It did.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think back in 2009 we had 9C cuts, which are really hard to do when you get notice in December and January, because you're basically cutting a year's worth of a cut in the 6th month.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're following quite closely.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion for approval of this first resolution?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On the motion as amended on resolution one.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion seconded roll call vote.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, 7 in the affirmative, 0 in the negative on the motion as amended.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Resolution 2, tax reform ballot question.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: talks about greater tax equity that will not raise taxes on any but the wealthiest residents of Massachusetts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Massachusetts Association of School Committees explore ways to promote social and economic equity through a valid initiative whose purpose may include a state constitutional amendment, tax reform, protection of the state's neediest residents of all ages, and seeks additional revenue only from tax reform affecting the state's wealthiest residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: FURTHER, THAT THE GOAL OF SUCH A BALLOT REFERENDUM WILL BE TO SECURE A STRONGER FINANCIAL BASE TO UNDERWRITE NEEDED IMPROVEMENTS IN THE INFRASTRUCTURE OF THE COMMONWEALTH, AS WELL AS THE EDUCATIONAL, SOCIAL, AND ECONOMIC WELL-BEING OF ITS RESIDENTS.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: IS THERE A MOTION ON THE FLOOR FOR APPROVAL OF THIS RESOLUTION NUMBER 2?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: MOTION FOR APPROVAL, MR. SCARI, SECONDED BY THE INTERCLUDE.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: ROLL CALL VOTE, PLEASE.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, 7 to 0, 7 in favor, motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Resolution 3, charter school reform.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Oh, this is a long one.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm going to go right down to the be it resolved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Therefore, be it resolved that the Massachusetts Association of School Committees urge the citizens of the Commonwealth to reject such a ballot initiative and further, that MASC seeks legislative approval of a comprehensive set of reforms that include, one, establishment of strict guidelines or regulations to require the charter schools enrolled represent cross-sections of students residing within the school service areas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Two, reporting of accurate number of students who leave charter schools to return to the sending district or district of residence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Three, requiring, well, I'm sorry, requiring the Mass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to retain and report accurate data on enrollment of students with learning disabilities, physical disabilities, economic disadvantage, emotional disability, and status as racial and linguistic minorities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: 4.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: State requirements that any charter school authorized in a community without its consent be funded in full by the Commonwealth, rather than by expropriation of Chapter 70 education aid from the sending cities, towns, and regions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: State funding in full of any mitigation funds created to offset the loss of state funding for students who become students in charter schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So noted that Mr. Benedetto will abstain based upon her working for a charter school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion for approval.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is the motion for approval by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Vanderhoof, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cugno.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Toscari.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cugno.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, 6 in the affirmative, 1 abstain, motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Resolution 4, social and emotional well-being of students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Som be it resolved that the Mass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Association of School Committees shall be directed to deploy such resources of the Association independently and in collaboration with other organizations to gather resources, identify strategies, and improve public awareness of the importance of addressing students' social and emotional well-being, and further, that MASC shall give consideration to such public policy initiatives that prioritize action by stakeholders and stakeholders

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: in collaboration with expert behavioral and health care providers as the most effective entities for addressing strategies that are in the best interest of children.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Over four million dollars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's on our cherry sheets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Anyone can go up to the state website and they can look up Medford's cherry sheet, which was named after the color it used to be printed on back in the dark ages.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you can look up the state aid, and you can see the revenue that comes from the state, expenses they charge us, such as tea.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They hit us for being a T community, which is quite a couple million dollars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Charter schools is another big hit that we have.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then you see the monies that come to the city from the state as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So please, go up and look.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's enlightening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yeah, I think the thing about the charter schools is we're not, like you said, we're not saying they're not great educational facilities, but when you pluck one first grader out of the school, maybe one first out of another school, we don't lose a whole classroom, so we don't gain any efficiencies.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We just, we lose one here and there, and the next thing you know, we're up to what number, Mr. Billeson?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: you know, all the different grades and schools and classrooms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So, we're not able to just cut classrooms, you know, without putting our numbers up to 25, 26 average, so.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Resolution proposed by Mayor Burke, proclamation by Mayor Burke, supporting and celebrating keeping lights on, keeping lights on after school of proclamation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Can I read this whole motion?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas the citizens of Medford stand firmly committed to quality after school programs and opportunities because they provide challenging and engaging learning experiences that help

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Children develop social, emotional, physical, and academic skills while supporting working families, ensuring their children are safe and productive after the traditional school day ends.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We, as the City of Medford, have provided significant leadership in the area of community involvement in the education and well-being of our youth, grounded in the principle that quality after-school programs are key to helping our children become successful adults.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Where as Lights On After School, the national celebration of after-school programs held this year on October 22, 2016, promotes the importance of quality after-school programs in the lives of children, families, and communities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Where as more than 28 million children in the U.S.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: have parents who work outside the home, and 15.1 million children have no place to go after school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Where as many after-school programs across the country are facing funding shortfalls so severe that they are being forced to close their doors and turn off their lights.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford City is committed to investing in the health and safety of all young people by providing after-school and out-of-school time programs that will help close the achievement gap and prepare young people to compete in the global economy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is important to engage families, schools, and communities in advancing the welfare of our children and ensure the lights stay on and the doors stay open for all children after school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now, the F.R.I.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Stephanie Burke, Mayor of the City of Medford, do hereby proclaim October 22, 2016 to be Lights On After School Day, and urge all the citizens of Medford to take cognizance of this event and participate fittingly in its observance, given this seventeenth day of October in the year 2016, and of the independence of the United States of America, the two hundred and forty.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion for approval.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm sorry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yep, sorry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, if I could, from the chair, I want to give some accolades out to Cache, who ran a fabulous event this past Saturday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was the Mystic River Celebration.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was a family-friendly event.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Many of the parents and children I saw were there all afternoon with great music, great dance, great activities for the kids.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it was just a really beautiful event.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I want to congratulate Laurel Siegel, Laura Beratin, the Medford Arts Council, Allie Fisk,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and their major donor, Brookline Bank, for pulling off an amazing event that I hope everybody got to come to, and if you didn't, make sure to put it on your calendar for next year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a fabulous day, so kudos to Cach for pulling that off.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much, Paula.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was a beautiful afternoon.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think if we all heard one common theme, it was peace and it was faith and it was what gets you through the day, basically.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the things that these people endured is just horrendous.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But there is a place now for people to reflect and meet and talk and look to the future.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it was a very proud day for the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My staff did an amazing job, as did others in City Hall, DPW, the state.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I mean, all hands were on deck for this event, so it was quite a nice afternoon.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have a special commendation for a lovely lady that is leaving our school district, so I'd like to ask Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Padvilli to step forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'd like to say that we have had this woman in our school system for the last 35 years, but it's only been two years, three months, four days, and she has accomplished so much in such a little amount of time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You're just an amazing woman.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You've brought some ingenious ideas to our school system, and you've certainly automated and made us a more productive system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This doesn't even reflect how we all feel about you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You know we adore you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But it's congratulations that Medford Public Schools is proud to recognize Patricia Bailey for outstanding service as the director of administration and finance, signed by all of us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we wish you the best in Minnesota.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yeah, Michigan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Michigan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we know that you and I can make another

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: very proud.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Here you go.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know we've been trying.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've been trying really, really hard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And just one other item, if you don't mind me taking it out of order.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'll give up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Would someone make a motion that we take item?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Tuscari.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to suspend the rules to take paper number eight of the reports out of order.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a report on complete streets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I hope that the community is aware that the city of Medford was awarded $400,000 for complete streets projects within our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This was part of a community compact that we signed with the governor's office and the lieutenant governor, which allowed us to basically get $90,000 worth of grant money in order to do studies of our streets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With that money, MAPC coordinated a team of traffic engineers and traffic advisors to come out and look at a lot of the issues that we are aware of and then to rank them based upon need.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Once we accomplished that, we had to put together a policy to submit to the state.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Once they approved, we were eligible for some extra points on our application.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We were awarded the full amount that you could for this process, which was $400,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The number one item on our list was the traffic walk in front of the Brooks School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We realized that the width of that area is just a tremendous amount of space and it's a safety hazard.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as recent as, I think, a week or so ago,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A child was grazed, but it could have been much worse.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It wasn't because of the width, it was a glare issue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But in any event, it's a very wide crosswalk.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the people at the tool design, which was our traffic consultants, they went through and they looked at it and they made a host of recommendations for this project, including rapid flash beacons, which is basically if you were going to cross, you press the button and

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: blinks go off on both sides, curb bump outs so that you're basically tightening the street, and a host of other signage and striping.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But in the interim, we're also going to be painting High Street because it is a very wide street going all the way down with cars being allowed to park in certain segments of it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we will be doing some immediate changes to the street to try and tighten it up a little bit and slow down the cars.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We know cars are an issue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The chief has guaranteed that he's going to have more enforcement on that street, and he will be addressing it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we had six items that were approved, one including Salem Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're doing a traffic study in the Salem Street, Haines Square area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford Square, we're tightening up the area in front of River Street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're going to make that a tighter walkway as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And there's a host of others in South Madrid in front of Tufts Pool.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We know we have a very dangerous crossing section there as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if you look up on the website, you can see the list of items that we're doing along with some analysis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we're just really proud to announce this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're also going to be looking at lowering the speed limits, which the state passed in August that the cities now have the authority to lower the street mileage on roads.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: before we couldn't touch state roads like Route 60, 16, 38.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And now they have passed that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are able to.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very pleased about that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've tried it in the past, and they've come down and taken down our signs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we will be intensifying this process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This intensifies it, this complete street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This funding source really does exemplify... Is there a timeline?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It has to be spent by June 30th.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have an engineer looking at the... When you do curb cuts, you have to have the proper radius and all of that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So someone actually has to spec out the plans that have to go on the street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we'll be specing that out over the next month.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The money's in hand right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then we'll be putting it out to bid to start as soon as winter's over, as soon as we're able to get in the ground, and then it'll be done probably by April, May.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The long-term plan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The short-term striping, we're going to be getting on that very shortly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Did we ever, you know, figure that out with... We had a meeting Thursday with a lot of the team from City Hall as well as some of the parents that were involved in the school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And this issue was brought to our attention at that meeting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we also had Senator Jalen and Rep.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Garbally, who was going to speak to Rep.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Donato.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's his district.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they were going to take that in their bailiwick, and they were going to address that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to send to rep Donato and Senator Jalen, a request for a traffic guard at the crosswalk on the fouls way between Salem street and Fulton street.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I believe that's the correct.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor, all those opposed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion is passed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Complete Streets isn't strictly a school zone area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ac yna byddai'n cael ei wneud, efallai, ym mis Mawrth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Dyna'n wych.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mae'n mynd i ddod ymlaen i'r dyfodol, a byddwn yn mynd i'r dyfodol ar hyn o bryd.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Rydyn ni'n cael cyfarfodydd ddiwethaf gyda llawer o'r tm o'r ystafell y ddinas, yn ogystal rhai o'r rhain o'r rhain o'r rhain o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai o'r rhai

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ac roedden nhw'n mynd i edrych mewn i'r broblemau DCR, oherwydd dyna'r ffyrdd DCR i weld a oedden nhw'n gallu, yn gyntaf, cael gartref ymlaen ar ddwy leoedd ar y Felswg.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Felly roedden nhw'n mynd i ddweud hynny yn eu Beiliwick, ac roedden nhw'n mynd i'w gysylltu hynny.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Rydw i'n gwneud y cyfrifiad i'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a'r sefydliadwyr a

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cress, roeddech chi am ddweud?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Complete Streets isn't strictly a school zone area.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They went in and they evaluated the level of severity, and they came up with the list.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's professional, not the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The professional engineers did.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they've ranked them all, and the state basically took our first six plus a study, seven items, and that's what they funded.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we'll be applying again for another grant, and we'll be going down that list and hitting more and more, and then whatever we can accomplish on our own will certainly be

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Dw i ddim yn gwybod, mae gennym nifer yma yn y cymdeithas rydyn ni'n gobeithio ei ystyried, ond dwi ddim wedi gweld y broblem hwnnw pan fydd y croesawd ar-lein.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Y broblem rydw i wedi clywed yw pan nad ydyn nhw yno, yw pan maen nhw'n cael broblemau.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Felly roedd y brif wedi dweud ei fod yn gwneud ymdrechion trafegol addas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Rydyn ni'n mynd i drimio rhai ddwyrau hefyd, er mwyn i bobl gweld y sylwad sy'n golygu beth yw eu cynyddiadau cyflym.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Rydyn ni'n meddwl mai'r broblem yw pan nad ydyn ni'n cael gwartref trafegol.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yn y cyfrifiad i'w cael mewn lle ar ddarlun, mae'r adroddiad hwn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yr holl bobl sy'n ymdrech.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yr holl bobl sy'n ymdrech.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mae'r cyfrifiad yn mynd dros.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mae'r cyfrifiad i ddod yn l i'r rhesymau arbennig.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Oh, nid ydw i. Dechreuwch.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Dechreuwch, Mr. Skerry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Y Llywodraeth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Y Llywodraeth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good afternoon dignitaries, clergy, friends, survivors, first responders, and especially the families of Crystal, Martin, Lindsey, and John.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Your strength and courage since September, April 15, 2013 has given us the ability to come together to heal from that traumatic time in the Commonwealth's history.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As a community, we share in your sorrow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As a community, we share in your healing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as a community, we are hopeful.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We are hopeful that this special place in our city, a living memorial that countless individuals, entities contributed to, to bring to fruition, is a testament to the longing we all have for a peaceful, reflective space.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I thank former Mayor Michael McGlynn for his vision and fortitude to plan this garden, which sits just a few blocks from the Campbell's residence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I thank Secretary Pollack, Highway Administrator Tom Tinlin, and their team for their expertise and funding to assist in this project.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I thank the Dagles, Pam Shadley, and all city departments for their work and oversight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We, the city and state, are a shepherd for this beautiful Peace Garden on behalf of all of those who gave us so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As versed by the Dalai Lama, when we meet real tragedy in life, we can react in two ways, either by losing hope and following self-destructive habits, or by using the challenge to find our inner strength.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In the days, weeks, and years following the horrific events, these families, first responders, and survivors have demonstrated pure strength by their actions and words seen and heard around the world.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Who can forget the words by Rob Rogers during his eulogy of his brother Sean Collier?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Live long like he would.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Big hearts, big smiles, big service, all love.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Who can forget Mr. Bill Richard's remarks during a recent dedication of a statue to his son Marvin at his and his wife Denise's alma mater, Bridgewater State University?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Reminder to all, unlike the past, the story of the future is not yet written.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Martin's message of peace will live on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our hope is for Martin's legacy to live on through today's children and to show that no matter the age, you can always choose kindness.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Who can forget Zheng Lu's expression at a memorial mass for his daughter, Lingzi?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: An ancient Chinese saying says, every child is actually a little Buddha that helps their parents mature and grow up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Even though we brought up Lingzi, and yet today, while reflecting on her short, 24-year life, we as parents admire and appreciate her kindness, courage, and her yearning for a beautiful life.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and who can forget Mr. Campbell's humble comments following the groundbreaking of this Garden of Peace.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But the weight is lifted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's like a rejoicing now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: No more sorrow.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You couldn't ask for any better.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Crystal would have loved it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're so lucky to have a community of people hearing so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's overwhelming, just beautiful.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To the Colliers, Lews, Richards, and Campbells, we are so proud to honor the memories of Sean, Lindsey, Martin, and Crystal, and remember the positive impact that they had on all of us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To the survivors, the courage, strength, and bond you built is an inspiration to all of us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To the first responders and ordinary people that ran to instead of from, you are our heroes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We all must remember that this Peace Garden not only signifies their memory, but also our commitment to observing peace every day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With this unveiling in the shadow of the International Day of Peace this past Wednesday, we must always remember Martin's message conveyed through a simple drawing of red full hearts and the words, no more hurting people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Peace.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: God bless you all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am stoked.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I got to kick it off last year when I was a candidate and now being there it's official.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm really excited to kick it off and get them started and start it safe and start it tight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: actually next Sunday we're unveiling the Crystal Campbell Peace Garden and it'll be a very special and very serious offer in some ways and yet looking towards the future of faith healing and camaraderie and peace.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really looking forward to next Sunday coming out at 2 o'clock at the Brighton-Medford Queer at the CrossFit Hotel.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Crystal Campbell Peace Garden unveiling.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On behalf of the entire city, we thank you and the whole team.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could just list the names of the other people.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Natella Taylor, Courtyard Nursing Home, Derek Marshine, Courtyard Nursing Home, Kelsey Flynn of Armstrong Ambulance, and Meredith Lambrook, also of Armstrong, Jesse Calvo of Hallmark, Mark Nicholas, Cataldo Ambulance, and Paul DeLiva, the principal of the Andrews, Janet Peralt, Hallmark Health, Lou Bracco, who's here tonight from the hospital, Sam is here as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So, Janet.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Wonderful.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you all so, so much on behalf of the students and our entire community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We really appreciate the hard work you put in on the kids' behalf.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Or as of Friday?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kindergarten is the average 21.5, grade 1 16.75, grade 2 22, grade 3 19.8, grade 4 18, and grade 5 18.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that is the average class size as of today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Right.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay, school committee resolutions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of the Honorable John J. McGlynn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: His honor was the former Medford Mayor, City Councilor, State Representative, and World War II Ghost Army Veteran.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was the devoted father of Attorney Jack McGlynn, Jr., Attorney Dickie McGlynn, Karen McGlynn-Devine, former Mayor Michael J. McGlynn, Bernadette Davis, and Kevin McGlynn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could just say from the chair, we all know what a champion this man was for our city, as is his family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He will be sorely missed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He gave a lot of advice to a lot of different people, and we're going to miss his face around our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We also have others.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Willard Bill Sampson.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Sampson was a retired school department custodian.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was the head custodian at Medford High School for many years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Sampson is the father of vocational teacher James Sampson.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Camille Mazzoni.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Mazzoni was a teacher in Medford for 35 years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Robert L. Ryan Sr.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Ryan was the father of District Attorney Marion Ryan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Margaret Weigel.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Weigel was a long-time Medford resident, educational technology consultant, co-founder of the Farmer's Market, and member of the Chevalier Theatre Commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She also served on the Medford Public Schools Technology Committee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And lastly, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Margaret Haynes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Haynes was a long-time teacher at the Gleason Elementary School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, we know yesterday was the observance of the 15th anniversary of September 11th, so if we could all please rise for a moment of silence on the loss of these Medford residents, former teachers and educators, and also commemorants of 9-11.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Skerry would like to say a few words.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Mr. Skerry.
