[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The special meeting of the Medford School Committee will now come to order.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Seven present, none absent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We will now rise to salute our flag.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Before we start this meeting, we're all aware that we lost a very special Medford citizen this past weekend, John Jack McGlynn, and it was a heartache for this community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was our former mayor and he certainly drove this city forward during the time that he spent leading this city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if we could all just take a moment of silence and dedicate this meeting in his memory, please rise.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is a special meeting of the Medford School Committee Monday, August 29, 2016 in the Library Resource Center at Medford High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The purpose of the meeting are to discuss the following.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Update report on the opening of the school year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Item number one, Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We did a site visit of a few different locations that were of serious concern, so we wanted to address those outside of the capital plan so that we felt that the children and parents and teachers were safe going in and out of the school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What's in the capital plan is above and beyond that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Just to refer to the Columbus, they went and they matched the paint because that concrete was treated with a stain.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They went and matched it so that it would fit in with what's there already.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they did spend a lot of time trying to work on things not to make it look like it's just going to get it done.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the crosswalk up here, I hope people notice the artistic crosswalk that was put in for them from the Arts Council.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yeah, it looks good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could, we got the contract today and I think last

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: spring I sent everyone a copy of what was in the application.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We received $250,000 from the state.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're doing lighting projects throughout all of the schools as part of that money.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In addition, some of the library is getting some lighting repaired as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we just got a signed copy today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So work will be going out to bid very shortly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, John.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Are there any other questions?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, John.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's an internal issue that we can determine on a committee by committee basis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The second item before you is the presentation and discussion of the capital plan proposals.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I guess before we get going on, the real details that are in this report is to keep in mind that this really is 100% wish list at this point.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Once we get the list compiled from all the different departments of the city, then we'll be better able to decide which projects can go forward in which years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So this is a cumulative list of things that we know, we're aware of, that we need to address.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we will be fine tuning them as we proceed in this process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, if I could, I didn't put this package together, the school department did, but obviously we've been looking at it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we have to realize that under Prop 2.5, there's only so much that we can raise through property taxes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So to the extent that we're not able to get MSBA funding on any of these projects, then obviously the burden falls to the city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we have to afford this along with other needs throughout the entire community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So until we have everything put together, the years really aren't relevant at this point.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The funding, what we can support is what's gonna drive how much we can do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This isn't going to drive what we can support.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What we can support will drive what we can do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's the only way it can work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's only a pie of money that we can spend, so.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could, I think your suggestion of visiting each school and going through the list that's here and then all of us deliberating at these public meetings at schools, then we can determine a priority list amongst what's here and what isn't here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that might be more beneficial than us just throwing why this, why that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It may be much more helpful to handle it that way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On the motion to move this to a committee of the whole and have site meetings at each of the locations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Seconded by Mr. Scari.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Aye.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion carries.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Superintendent just before we start the interviews I think at this point we really need to recognize the work of Pat Bailey.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She's been just a fabulous addition to the school department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The things that she has introduced to us and streamlined processes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You're just an amazing woman Pat and we're very lucky to have had you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're going to miss you desperately but we wish you the best when you relocate with your family.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and we fond memories go, fond thoughts are always being thrown your way so we wish you the best of luck and we will miss you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a grant right now that we're looking at.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We signed the compact with the governor's office to review all of our financial products.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Excellent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's being reviewed as we speak.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Could you describe in a little greater detail your procurement experience?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I don't know if in earlier interviews they explained that we're centralized procurement officers at City Hall, but it is always helpful to have the school department that can take the ball and kind of take it almost to the end zone.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I was wondering if you could describe your procurement experience and maybe some of the projects that you've worked on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Were you part of the project team for the major construction projects that you were?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, you were.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We spoke a little bit about bus scheduling, I think, earlier.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Do you take care of that at your current district, or is it left to someone else?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: How many unions are you currently involved with?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Are your teachers paid on a 10 month basis or every union 12 months, 52 weeks?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay, so similar to what we have, and you're familiar with different pay cycles and all of that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And you've also sat at the bargaining table as well?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Have you ever used admins?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Right now we have a lot of bridges from hoppers payroll into admins which is the financial software and we have another software for our Treasury Department which is where all the cash deposits go.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's three systems all trying to work together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I'm really hopeful that we'll be able to streamline

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: but it will be a difficult process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Sounds like something you've already undertaken.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We'll take a five minute recess.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Do you have any direct procurement experience?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: in Fitchburg?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Have you been involved with any MSBA projects in the city?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Take a short break.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Do you have a decentralized procurement process in Arlington, or do you answer to the town manager's office or the SCPPO?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So almost all procurement, budgetary procurement, goes on through the school system with no approval levels?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: on the municipal side?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So you put together RFPs, RFIs, all sorts of different.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is that the last project that you worked on?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: How many unions do you work with in the school department?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Are you a member of the bargaining team?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Just one, just to spoof up some of the earlier questions, have you ever seen the admins financial package?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I haven't.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I have not.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Have you been part of any conversions?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good afternoon, this is Stephanie Muccini-Burke, and I'm here from the mayor's office at Medford City Hall.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much for tuning in today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm pleased to introduce you to one of the transition teams that we had in place.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's the economic development transition team.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They spent quite a bit of time over the course of the last several months meeting with the businesses and residents throughout our community in the various squares in order to bring forth a plan called Shaping Medford, which we're really proud to highlight today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We'll give you a brief report on the comprehensive committee work called Shaping Medford and some of the initiatives that we already have in place today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The Business and Economic Development Committee is one of four teams that I put in place shortly after being elected.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We had the City Hall Audit Team, the Cultural Affairs and Recreation Team, as well as the Constituent Service Team.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Behind me are committee members for the Business and Economic Development Committee, which was led by Co-Chair Rick Orlando, Co-Chair Fred Dello Russo, President of the City Council,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Members Muhammad Chowdhury, Christine Cousineau, Paul Matarazzo, Kelly Herstack, Tim McGibbon, and Linda Garriott.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'd like to thank these committee members for taking part in this experiment and for their expertise and the commitment of time that they put forth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They met countless hours with some of the residents in the community to try and bring forth the best plan possible.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they gave up quite a bit of their personal time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And for that, I'm very appreciative to all of you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Further, this report would not have been possible without the community members that took part in all of these meetings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We try to value your input and hopefully when we come back out and meet with you, you'll see what has come from all of the discussions that were taking place along small tables and large conference rooms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's an important time in Medford with an influx of new residents, businesses, and nationwide focus on walkability and placemaking.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My administration is dedicated to making strides to enhance Medford's

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: appeal as a place to live, play, and work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Economic and business development are at the heart of this effort.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And this committee was key to providing detailed and geographically specific feedback that will guide the many important conversations and initiatives currently taking place and future initiatives that will take place.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: At this point, I'd like to introduce Rick Orlando, the co-chair of the committee, who will provide a little bit of information on the process and some of the basic findings of the report.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Orlando.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much, Rick.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think when people take the time and read the report, they're going to be astounded by some of the ideas that came from these various community business district meetings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And there really are some fabulous ideas, really out-of-the-box ideas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I thank you all for bringing it all together for us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To follow up on this report over the next two months, we plan on bringing it to the streets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we plan on revisiting the sections of the city to bring people back to the table so that they can hear the outcomes from all of their comments and to see the next steps that the city plans on taking in order to initiate some of these grand ideas.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, I'm pleased to say that we're moving forward with some very important initiatives.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You heard Rick speak about safety and crosswalks and bike accessibility issues.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we do have several initiatives that are on the front right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One is the complete streets process, which our city engineer will be speaking about shortly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Medford Square revitalization plan.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Releasing a business guide to help new businesses navigate the different requirements and permits that are required to open up their shop.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Strengthening our relationship with the chamber, which we think is at the forefront that we need to do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And other business coalitions that are throughout the community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and exploring ways to actively invite businesses to Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And one of the key aspects of that is we were able, with the City Council's vote for appropriation this past June, to add two new positions to the Office of Community Development.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think that is vital to initiating and bringing some of these ideas forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we look forward to bringing on these new staff positions and seeing the work that they will do to help the Office of Community Development flourish.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: With that being said, I'd like to introduce Lauren DiLorenzo.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She is the Director of our Office of Community Development.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She's gonna speak a little bit about the Method Square process that really is the jumping off from all the work that these fine people behind me did.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Lauren, if you could step forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Lauren.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, one of the first initiatives we undertook upon being sworn in was signing on to the community compact with the Governor's office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Lieutenant Governor Perlito did come out and meet with us and we signed the compact together in this office a few months ago.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the item that Lauren just spoke about, the Medford Square Master Plan, was part of

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: agreement that we made with the Commonwealth of Mass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we thank them for being a party in all the work that we're doing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the next initiative that we undertook was a complete streets policy initiative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Cassandra is going to update us on that right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Cassandra Kudlitas, City Engineer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much, Cassandra.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm just really proud to say that the projects that Cassandra just spoke about, they amount to about $400,000, and they've been funded through the Complete Streets grant program.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really, really pleased that the governor's office and DOT, they've all approved our plans, and the hard work that Cassandra and her office have done, as well as the bike commission and the pedestrian committee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A lot of people have put their thoughts into some of the ideas that now will be done in the near future.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really happy with the

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: citizen engagement, and the way that people are willing to give up their time to make Medford a better community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're really proud of those two aspects.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Next, I have Allie Fisk from our office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She is our business liaison.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She's been working very closely with the Chamber of Commerce, some of the people behind me here, and a host of other cultural and arts people in our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She wants to bring you up to date on a business guide that was one of our priority items back in January.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Allie, take it away.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much, Allie.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A lot of work has gone into that, and we do have a good draft that we have circulated to a few business owners from the chamber, and also some of the newer businesses that just opened up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We wanted to get their feedback.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They've just gone through the entire process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We wanted to see what made sense and the sequencing of doing things, so we're very eager to get their input over the course of the next week, and then it will go to publication.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much, Ally, for spearheading that and we're just really, really proud of the work that the department heads are doing on behalf of the citizens of Medford and the business owners in this city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Just before I leave you, I just wanted to bring you up to date on a couple of events that will be taking place over the next two months.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: September 25th at 2 p.m., we will be unveiling the Crystal Campbell Peace Garden that Lauren DiLorenzo spoke of earlier.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're very excited to show that location, the peacefulness, the tranquility.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and to pay our respects for those that lost their lives or that are suffering to this day from the bombing accident.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, on October 23rd at 1 o'clock, we will be having Medford Day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is a community day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We envision it highlighting the diversity of our community, the many multi-cultures that traverse our streets and take part in our school systems and dance and music.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're very excited to have that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we'll be behind the Andrews Middle School once again.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we're very eager, so if you have any interest in playing a role in that day, reach out to the mayor's office and we'll certainly get back to you and organize your event.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: help to allow you to participate in that day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On behalf of the whole mayor's staff, I thank the committee members for all of their hard work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're a fabulous group, very articulate, very educated, very invested.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And without them, we could not have done the work that we did.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much for participating, and we look forward to working with you into the future.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.
